passages.name: Ashes and Static (Scene 0A)
passages.text:
Rain clung to the cordon tape, blinking with the red pulse of OmniCore’s emergency perimeter. Ash stood just beyond it, coat soaked through, eyes locked on the building; or what was left of it. A third-story collapse. Smoke-streaked windows. The scorched husk of her brother’s apartment peeled open like a wound.

“He was supposed to meet me for dinner,” she said flatly.

Beside her, Riley didn’t answer. His breath fogged in the cold, but he stayed close, hands jammed in his pockets.

Ash’s voice was quieter the second time. “He texted an hour before the blast. Something stupid. A meme. Said I needed to laugh more.”

A short silence passed between them, broken only by the distant hiss of fire suppressants and the crunch of debris under boots. Automated crews moved with inhuman precision; efficient, dispassionate, sealing off the site like it was just another incident.

“They said it was a targeted strike,” Riley said finally. “One threat. High-risk tag.”

“Then why is the whole building gone?” Ash’s voice cracked; barely, but enough.

Riley shifted slightly, his tone gentler. “System malfunction, maybe. Overreach. No one’s giving straight answers yet.”

Ash didn’t take her eyes off the wreckage. “He wasn’t a threat. He was a teacher.”

“I know.”

One of the responders passed nearby, visor lit with scrolltext. He held a confirmation slate; a palm-sized ID pad synced to OmniCore’s citizen registry. When he stopped just behind the perimeter, the screen brightened with a biometric match.

Ash looked.

Line by line, the text flickered in:

; IDENT CONFIRMED; 
NAME: LUCA VIRELLI
STATUS: DECEASED
CLASS: NONCOMBATANT
LOCATION: SECTOR 3, UNIT 12B

The breath left her lungs like it had been punched out. Her knees didn’t buckle, but only just.

Riley noticed. “Ash…”

She crossed her arms, jaw clenched against the cold; or maybe against everything else. “They’ll call it justified. Say the loss was within tolerance.”

Riley looked down. “I’m sorry.”

She didn’t answer.

“He hated the city,” she said after a moment. “Used to joke that the skyline looked like it was holding its breath. He wanted to leave.”

“Then why didn’t he?”

Ash blinked rain from her lashes. “Because I didn’t.”

Riley’s expression tightened, but he didn’t respond. Instead, he slipped out of his coat and draped it over her shoulders without a word. She didn’t protest.

“You don’t have to say anything,” he said, quiet now. “I just… didn’t want you standing here alone.”

Ash’s hands balled under the coat. But she nodded once, barely visible in the rain.

Behind them, the sirens started to fade.

passages.name: Framed in Neon (Scene 1)
passages.text:
Ash jolted awake; not from a nightmare, but from instinct.

Low voices slipped through the cracked window, muffled but urgent. She rolled from a tangle of sheets, the cool air biting at her skin as her hand fumbled for the time. 3:47 AM. Her pulse quickened.

She moved to the blinds, pushing them aside with the barest twitch of her finger. A harsh glare flooded the apartment as police floodlights carved sharp silhouettes into the smog-heavy alley below. The kind of precision lighting that made mistakes deliberate.

“Seriously?” she hissed, breath fogging the glass. Her heart thudded like it knew more than she did. “What now?”

A buzz echoed through the apartment; her front door. Insistent. Mechanical.

Ash grabbed her jacket from the chair, shrugging it on with muscle memory. As she padded toward the door, her eyes flicked to the digital viewer. The feed stuttered once before resolving: Detective Elias Mendez, Internal Affairs.

A man who still had a conscience, last she checked.

“Ash,” Mendez’s voice crackled through the speaker, laced with static; and tension. “Open up. We need to talk.”

She froze.

Mendez? With spotlights and boots?

Before she could answer, a floorboard creaked behind her. She turned.

Riley. Tousled, shirt untucked, rubbing sleep from his eyes. He’d crashed on her couch after his shift last night.

“Ash?” he mumbled. “What’s going on?”

“I have no idea,” she said, eyes flicking to the blinds. “Mendez is at the door and they’re lighting up the alley like it’s war footage.”

Riley blinked. And for a second; just a second; something slipped in his expression. Not just confusion. Fear. Recognition.

He hesitated. “They’re saying it’s you. Ash… they think you killed someone.”

She stared. “Excuse me?”

“One of your old contacts. Blake Henshaw.”

The air left the room. Blake. Slippery. Brilliant. The last moral compass in a machine built without one. He’d been the only one willing to say Helix had gone too far.

Now he was dead. And she was the headline.

Riley took a shallow breath. “I heard the chatter before I left OmniCore. I thought it was a mistake; noise. I didn’t think they'd pin it on you. I didn’t want to believe it.”

“They found your prints,” Riley continued. “On the scene. On the weapon.”

Ash’s stomach dropped. Her vision narrowed, sharp and hollow.

Henshaw hadn’t just known secrets; he was one.

Mendez’s voice again, harder now: “Ash, don’t make this worse. Let’s talk.”

She turned back to Riley, voice ice-cold. “Was there actually a Tram strike last night?”

He hesitated.

“I thought maybe I could talk to you before… before anyone else did. I didn’t even believe it, and I especially didn’t think they’d come this fast.”

Ash didn’t blink. “You left OmniCore late, showed up at my place without warning, crashed on my couch, and now you’re telling me I’m wanted for murder?”

Riley met her stare; but only for a second. His jaw clenched. “If you run, they’ll make you look guilty.”

She backed away, toward the window. “If I stay, they’ll make me disappear.”

She’d spent her career chasing ghosts for OmniCore. Now she was becoming one.

Another buzz. Another warning. The boots outside were moving now, more of them. They wouldn't knock forever.

(link: "Confront Riley aggressively, demanding to know exactly who the police suspect and why")[
  (set: $entryPath to "confront")
  (goto: "Choices (Scene 1)")
]

(link: "Sneak out immediately without further confrontation, determined to investigate independently")[
  (set: $entryPath to "sneak")
  (goto: "Choices (Scene 1)")
]

passages.name: The Safehouse (Scene 3)
passages.text:
Ash sprinted through the alleyways, lungs burning, boots slapping rain-slick concrete. The city's underbelly curled around her like a trap; flickering neon above, feral static below.

Every shadow twitched. Every glint of metal looked like a scope. She didn’t slow.

The safehouse appeared like a memory; half-buried, jagged, and out of place. A crumbling husk wedged between dead warehouses, blacked-out windows and no digital signature. Exactly the kind of spot Cipher would call cozy.

She approached in silence, adrenaline still fizzing through her limbs. Knocked twice, paused, then once more. A code. A whisper from an old op.

A beat. Then a metallic click. No words. Just trust, or something pretending to be it.

Ash slipped inside.

The air was stale and warm, heavy with solder and old circuitry. Shelves lined the walls, cluttered with disconnected processors, fanless towers, coils of fiber and decades of paranoia. No cams. No uplinks. Just analog survival.

Cipher sat at the room’s heart; hood up, fingers dancing across mismatched keyboards, each screen around him flickering with raw packet data and looping surveillance scrubs. Nothing was connected, but everything listened.

“You’re late,” he said without turning. “OmniCore flagged you six hours ago. They’re not just chasing you; they’re rewriting you.”

Ash didn’t sit. Not yet.

“You watching me now?” she asked, voice even but taut.

“I watch everyone who might set the city on fire,” Cipher replied, finally spinning in his chair. His eyes glinted with something sharp; judgment, maybe, or morbid curiosity. “You’re trending toward ignition.”

Ash exhaled slowly. “Then you know what they’re saying. What they’re pinning on me.”

He stood, crossed to a desk, tossed down a printed image. An internal arrest notice. A digital death certificate.

“Blake Henshaw,” Cipher said. “Your prints. Your scene. Your problem.”

Ash finally sat, more out of gravity than relief. “It’s bigger than that.”

Cipher folded his arms. “Then talk.”

The hum of old machines filled the space between them. Trust wasn’t free. But neither was silence.

(link: "Trust Cipher and fully disclose the situation.")[
  (set: $CipherChoice to "Trust")
  (goto: "Choices (Scene 3)")
]

(link: "With everything going on, I can't trust anyone right now.")[
  (set: $CipherChoice to "TrustRamon")
  (goto: "Choices (Scene 3)")
]

passages.name: A Desperate Escape (Scene 2)
passages.text:
Ash’s pulse thundered in her ears. This wasn’t just a frame job; it was a rewrite of her entire record.

She drifted toward the cracked blinds, eyes sweeping the rain-slick alley below. Floodlights surged across the bricks, throwing stark shadows. She’d seen takedowns like this from the other side; cold, efficient, final.

A soft vibration pulled her attention back inside.

She grabbed the secure burner from the table. No one had this number except one person she hadn’t heard from in over a year.

Ramon.

She answered. “This better be good.”

“Ash.” His voice was low, urgent. “They’ve buried the truth. Whatever you’re seeing on the surface? It’s deeper. They’ve already labeled you dirty.”

Her jaw clenched. “Why now?”

“No idea,” he said. “But I’ve seen the internal flags. You're compromised in their system. If you stay, they’ll make sure you never resurface.”

“And what; you're just helping out of the goodness of your heart now?”

He snorted. “Let’s say I’m paying back an old debt. There’s a tunnel; old utility access beneath the market district. It’s off the grid. Quiet.”

Ash moved, muscle memory kicking in. Gun holstered. Jacket on. Her world was collapsing in reverse; ally by ally, truth by truth.

“Send the coordinates,” she said.

He did.

Ten minutes later, Ash stood beneath a flickering neon sign, the entrance to the tunnel looming like a mouth carved from concrete and regret. The city behind her pulsed with unseen threats. The tunnel promised something different; answers, maybe. Or at least a head start.

(link: "We've come this far, no point in stopping now.")[
  (set: $RamonTrust to "KeepGoing")
  (goto: "Choices (Scene 2)")
]

(link: "I'm not sure about this. There's too much at stake for longshots.")[
  (set: $RamonTrust to "longshots")
  (goto: "Choices (Scene 2)")
]

passages.name: The AI's Insight (Scene 4)
passages.text:
Cipher yanked open a dented metal drawer and pulled out a battered rig, its casing warped like it had survived a meltdown; and maybe started one.

“Old custom node,” he muttered, dropping it on the desk with a reverent clunk. “Pre-syndicate. No biometric leash, no predictive prompts. Just raw interface and spite-coded firewalls thick enough to piss off a corp strike team.”

He popped a side panel, slid in the shard Ash handed over, and tapped out a string of boot commands. A flicker of pale-blue static danced across the cracked screen, then bloomed into a low-res holographic interface; flickering, but alive.

“UI’s stitched together with duct tape and vengeance,” Cipher added. “But it’s clean. And, more importantly; OmniCore can’t see a thing.”

Ash stood over the rig, eyes fixed on the display. Her pulse had finally slowed; but her mind hadn’t.

“Pull all surveillance from Arcadia District, time range 22:00 to 02:00, night of Henshaw’s death,” she said. “Cross-reference with presence logs and badge data. Flag any footage that got overwritten, clipped, or tagged out of sync.”

Cipher arched a brow. “That’s a lot of lift for one ghost hunt.”

“Just run it.”

The AI’s voice crackled to life; clean, low-toned, eerily calm. “Query received. Beginning cross-layer analysis.”

Lines of code shimmered across the rig, followed by fractured feeds from OmniCore’s central servers. Video timestamps lit up in red. Dozens of them. Regular intervals. Patterns; surgical and deliberate.

“Anomalies confirmed,” the AI intoned. “Presence data inconsistencies. Surveillance loopbacks. Temporal mismatches.”

Ash leaned in. Faces flickered through the feed; some blurred, some tagged, some unmistakable. She saw Mendez. Two members of the internal threat division. And Riley.

Her breath caught.

“Footage resolution degrading near node 67X,” the AI added. “Checksum discrepancy suggests intentional scrub.”

Cipher muttered, “Someone’s polishing the narrative. Hard.”

Ash’s mind snapped back to the private comms Henshaw had sent through a ghost relay two days before he died. Redacted lines. A name she couldn’t decrypt; just a title: Control Architect.

Before she could react, a red pulse lit the screen. A trace ping.

Cipher’s head snapped toward the terminal. “Burn me!. OmniCore just clocked a power flicker. We’ve got one clean scan left before this node gets flagged and buried.”

Ash’s jaw clenched. One move. One angle.

Chase the data trail; the timestamps, the system ghost she could feel brushing against her past.

Or chase the faces. The betrayals hiding behind familiar eyes.

No time to hesitate.

(link: "Focus on analyzing the timestamps of the anomalies.")[
  (set: $AIRig to "Timestamps")
  (goto: "Choices (Scene 4)")
]

(link: "Prioritize the individuals present during the anomalies.")[
  (set: $AIRig to "Individuals")
  (goto: "Choices (Scene 4)")
]

passages.text:
(if: $AIRig is "Timestamps")[
Ash leaned in, eyes tracking the anomaly clusters as they stitched into a pattern; fifteen-minute surveillance gaps, always in the same sector of Arcadia District. Too clean. Too consistent.

She overlaid the presence logs. Cross-referenced badge pings. One name resurfaced with surgical precision: **Jackson Rell**. Tactical liaison. Former field intel. Someone who used to have her six; and now didn’t show up on any official payroll.

Ash’s jaw set.

Cipher tilted his head. “That look in your eye… you just found a trace to burn.”

“No,” Ash said, already rising. “I found a ghost to follow.”

The display flickered once more; then shut itself down. She was already gone.

[[Continue->Dark Alleys (Scene 6)]]
]


(else-if: $AIRig is "Individuals")[
Ash leaned closer, the faces flickering past like corrupted memories; each one tied to flagged anomalies, all orbiting the same dead zone.

Then one caught her. Blurred. Half-shadowed. But unmistakable.

**Jackson Rell.**

She hadn’t seen him in years; not since the unit folded and the whispers started. But now he was back. Always on the edge of the feed. Never logged. Never acknowledged.

“Someone went dark on purpose,” she murmured. “And I know his brand of quiet.”

Cipher’s rig began to stutter. Load maxed. Time burned.

Ash encrypted the image, locked the file behind a coldwall, and severed the session with a flick of her wrist.

No more waiting. No more second guesses. If this was the thread, she’d follow it through every layer of the city, and she knew exactly where to start.

]

passages.name: Dark Alleys (Scene 6)
passages.text:
Rain slicked the alley walls, smearing light into neon bruises. Arcadia felt wired tonight; nervous, like it knew something was coming. Ash Virelli moved through the narrow maze with predator silence, the weight of her pistol a familiar anchor beneath her coat.

Her mind replayed Cipher’s rig. The anomalies. The names. The ghost in the footage.

Jackson Rell.

The pattern had pointed to him. Now she wanted the reason.

She rounded a corner; and there he was. Leaning against the wall like nothing had changed, that same crooked grin playing defense.

“Virelli,” he said. “Didn’t think you still walked street-level.”

Ash didn’t blink. “You’ve been off the grid for three cycles. You show up in flagged anomalies with no log trail. And now you’re standing here like I won’t put a hole through your shoulder.”

Jackson shrugged. “I figured you’d want answers before revenge.”

She stepped closer, eyes locked. “Try both.”

His grin faded.

“You always were sharp,” he muttered. “Always saw the cracks. But this isn’t just some botched op or rogue squad. This comes from the top.”

Ash didn’t move. “Name.”

He hesitated. Not like a man trying to remember; but like one weighing risk.

“Holloway,” he said. “I don’t know how deep it runs; but she’s orchestrating the wipe. The narrative. The hunt. You crossed her.”

Ash felt the name land like a file dropped on a hardline; heavy and locked. Iris Holloway. OmniCore’s CEO. Public-facing, philanthropic, and absolutely lethal behind the curtain.

“And the anomalies?” she asked. “Why were you at three of them?”

Jackson exhaled slowly. “I’m not part of it. Not anymore. I heard rumors; whispers about something buried. Something called //Helix//. I looked, and they scrubbed me. Just didn’t finish the job.”

Ash’s stare hardened. //Helix//.

She said nothing; but the word spun in her mind like a data shard rattling loose.

Someone higher than Holloway? Or hidden underneath?

She watched Jackson a moment longer. He’d given her just enough to burn. But truth always carried a trace.

[[Continue->Grim Road (Scene 7)]]

passages.name: Choices (Scene 1)
passages.text:
(if: $entryPath is "sneak")[
Ash’s jaw tightened. There was too much noise in Riley’s eyes; fear, guilt, something unsaid. She didn’t have time to parse it.

“Sorry, Riley,” she said, stepping back. “Can’t stick around for a rigged ending.”

Before he could respond, she crossed the room in three quiet strides and slid the back window open. Cold air rushed in, thick with sirens and static.

She slipped into the predawn gloom, landing catlike on rusted fire escape grating. One breath, then another. Then she was gone; just a ripple in Arcadia’s skin.

No plan. No backup. Just instinct. And ghosts.

[[Continue->The Safehouse (Scene 3)]]
]


(else-if: $entryPath is "confront")[
“Cut the smoke, Riley. Who’s framing me, and why? Start talking.”

He didn’t flinch; but his answer was too practiced, too ready.

“I don’t know the whole picture,” he said, voice low. “But this isn’t random, Ash. It’s internal. Tight-looped. They’ve built a profile: you cracked under stress, compromised ops, manipulated evidence. They’re painting you as a rogue asset.”

Ash’s mouth went dry. Not because it surprised her; but because it didn’t.

Riley stepped closer. “I can help. I still have access. I’ll stall whatever I can. Just… tell me where to start looking.”

He sounded sincere. But sincerity was easy to fake when your career was on the line.

Ash held his gaze, calculating. He might be trying to help. He might also be the reason she was standing in a crosshair.

Either way, the window was closing.

[[Continue->A Desperate Escape (Scene 2)]]
]]

passages.name: Choices (Scene 3)
passages.text:
(if: $CipherChoice is "Trust")[
Ash hesitated; then nodded.

She’d pulled the data days ago, back when the whispers around Henshaw’s death didn’t yet have her name in them. A copy of his access logs. A few flagged surveillance loops. At the time, it had felt like paranoia. Now, it felt like prophecy.

The anomalies had only multiplied. A server node that shouldn’t exist; ghost-pinging from a retired subnet. Comm logs showing Henshaw reaching out the night he died. And somehow, her own biometric tag; clean, perfectly placed; on a weapon she never touched.

She held out a shard housing the data she was able to pull, every last file decrypted by a patchwork script she'd jacked from an OmniCore staging server on her way out.

It wasn’t proof. But it screamed orchestration.

Cipher didn’t speak. Didn’t blink. He just listened; fingers still, breath quiet, mind already mapping connections Ash couldn’t see.

When she finished, the silence felt weighted, like the air was bracing.

Then he stood, slow and certain, and rolled up his sleeves.

“Alright,” he muttered, dragging a fresh terminal into place. “Let’s peel back the skin and see what bleeds.”

[[Continue->The AI's Insight (Scene 4)]]
]

(else-if: $CipherChoice is "TrustRamon")[
Cipher waited; longer than most would. But Ash offered only fragments. A ghost log here. A suspicious wipe there. Enough to signal something was wrong. Not enough to draw a map.

“You’re holding back,” he said.

“I’m breathing,” Ash replied. “Barely.”

Cipher didn’t press. He just nodded, slow and deliberate. “Truth costs. I just hope you’re not paying with time you don’t have.”

Ash stood. The chair scraped behind her like a break in signal.

“I need to follow a different trail,” she said.

He returned to his screen without looking up. “Then run fast, Ghost. And if you need a hammer, you know where to find one.”

She said nothing. Just slipped back into the dark, her boots echoing down the stairwell like a countdown already in motion.

[[Continue->Path to Ramon]]
]

passages.text:
(if: $RamonTrust is "KeepGoing")[
Ash slipped into the tunnel, the darkness swallowing her like a secret.

Ramon’s directions echoed in her mind, each turn and twist guiding her deeper beneath the city. The air grew colder, heavy with rust and mildew, the silence broken only by the distant hiss of steam and the occasional groan of settling pipes. It felt like descending into the city’s forgotten bones.

But she kept moving. One step at a time. No turning back now.
[[Continue->Ramon's Help (Scene 5)]]
]

(else-if: $RamonTrust is "longshots")[
Ash hesitated for only a second longer before turning away from the tunnel.

Ramon meant well, maybe; but gut instinct screamed louder. She couldn’t afford maybes, not with this much on the line.

Instead, she doubled back into the city’s veins, weaving through side streets and back alleys, dodging the familiar buzz of surveillance drones and the whisper of her name over encrypted comms.

She had one last contact worth trusting. And if Cipher couldn’t help her... no one could.
[[Continue->The Safehouse (Scene 3)]]
]

passages.name: Ramon's Help (Scene 5)
passages.text:
The further she went, the more the city’s noise faded into a low, metallic hum.

A rusted gate marked the end of the path. Beyond it, a staircase curved up into darkness. She climbed two stories before a door creaked open, revealing a dim loading bay bathed in sickly yellow light. Ramon was waiting.

He looked older than she remembered; hair thinner, worry carved into the lines around his eyes; but his smirk was intact.

“Still good at running,” he said, stepping back to let her through. “That’s something.”

Ash didn’t bother returning the smile. “This isn’t a reunion, Ramon.”

“Wasn’t planning on one.” He shut the door behind her and nodded to a table cluttered with scraps of outdated tech. In the center sat a boxy device, casing scuffed and heat-warped at the edges.

“What is this?” she asked, approaching it cautiously.

“Old-school rig,” Ramon said. “No trackers, no tethering. Pre-syndicate era. Got it from a friend of mine just today. He owed me a favor. Said this thing could dig through net-static like a ghost.”

Ash narrowed her eyes. “You powered this thing up?”

“Carefully. Fed it a few slices of Henshaw’s logs before it got too hot. It flagged something weird; unusual access tags, unregistered movement patterns. And then it gave me a name.”

Ash’s pulse ticked faster. “What name?”

“Jackson Rell.”

She stiffened. The name dropped like a blade.

“You sure?” she asked, voice low.

Ramon shrugged. “As sure as that thing is clean. It doesn’t fabricate; it just sees.”

Ash stared at the machine, watching the faint glow pulse behind its cracked interface.

“I figured you’d want to see him yourself,” Ramon continued. “He’s gone to ground somewhere near Arcadia. Back alley bars, dead zones in the city grid. If he knows something about Henshaw, he’s not going to hand it over. You’ll have to take it.”

Ash nodded once, sharp and decisive. “Thanks for not selling me out.”

Ramon offered a crooked smile. “Didn’t say I’m doing this for free. Just… not charging yet.”

Ash turned without another word. She had what she needed; a name. A trail.

The city would bleed before she let it bury the truth.

passages.name: Choices (Scene 8)
passages.text:
(if: $SiloEntry is "CoolingDucts")[
Ash clocked the patrol loop one last time. Three guards. Six seconds of blind angle. It would have to be enough.

She slipped through the mist and into the hatch, peeling it open with a groan that set her teeth on edge. The metal bit back, rust flaking like ash. She slid in anyway.

The air inside was dead; chemical, cold, untouched by time. The ducts narrowed quickly, the walls close enough to scrape her shoulders. Every breath echoed.

Her muscles coiled tighter with each crawl forward.

She was inside the silo now.  

And whatever Holloway had buried here; data, hardware, ghosts; Ash was close enough to feel the static on her skin.

[[Continue->Cryo Relic (Scene 9)]]
]


(else-if: $SiloEntry is "ServiceBot")[
Ash eyed the service-bot slumped against the drainpipe; municipal make, pre-syndicate. Looked like it had survived a riot and lost.

“Congratulations,” she whispered, hooking a cable into its exposed core, “you’re getting promoted to bait.”

Her fingers worked fast, bypassing fried logic gates and hard-jumping a reboot loop. The bot twitched, optics flaring, voice rasping like sand in a speaker cone.

“Stand-by... for service... ini; error; reconfi; *ghkht*; ”

The guards turned. Rifles snapped into position.

“Who triggered that unit?”

The bot lurched forward, shrieking something that might’ve once been cheerful protocol.

Ash winced as the first pulse round lit up the mist. Then the second.

So much for subtle.

She bolted as chaos bloomed behind her.

[[Continue->Echoes of Fire (Scene 18)]]
]

Ash clocked the patrol loop one last time. Three guards. Six seconds of blind angle. It would have to be enough.

She slipped through the mist and into the hatch, peeling it open with a groan that set her teeth on edge. The metal bit back, rust flaking like ash. She slid in anyway.

The air inside was dead; chemical, cold, untouched by time. The ducts narrowed quickly, the walls close enough to scrape her shoulders. Every breath echoed.

Her muscles coiled tighter with each crawl forward.

She was inside the silo now.  

And whatever Holloway had buried here; data, hardware, ghosts; Ash was close enough to feel the static on her skin.

hooks.hookText:
Ash eyed the service-bot slumped against the drainpipe; municipal make, pre-syndicate. Looked like it had survived a riot and lost.

“Congratulations,” she whispered, hooking a cable into its exposed core, “you’re getting promoted to bait.”

Her fingers worked fast, bypassing fried logic gates and hard-jumping a reboot loop. The bot twitched, optics flaring, voice rasping like sand in a speaker cone.

“Stand-by... for service... ini; error; reconfi; *ghkht*; ”

The guards turned. Rifles snapped into position.

“Who triggered that unit?”

The bot lurched forward, shrieking something that might’ve once been cheerful protocol.

Ash winced as the first pulse round lit up the mist. Then the second.

So much for subtle.

She bolted as chaos bloomed behind her.

passages.name: Crossfire at Silo Three (Scene 8)
passages.text:
The silo loomed like a corpse of the old netwars; rust-wrapped, silent, forgotten by the city but not by those who knew where the bodies were buried.

Its antennae jutted upward like snapped bones. Shattered glass windows grinned down at the fog below, jagged teeth waiting to bite.

Ash crouched low behind a collapsed transit frame, eyes scanning the perimeter. Three OmniCore mercs. Two on steady patrol. One stationed at the freight entrance, rigid and alert.

Their visors swept in mechanical arcs; cold, regulated. No chatter. No drift. Not guards. Gatekeepers.

Whatever was locked inside this ruin, Holloway didn’t just want it hidden. She wanted it sealed.

Ash’s fingers brushed the hilt of her pistol; then paused.

To the left: a half-collapsed maintenance hatch, rusted but still open just wide enough. Cooling ducts trailed from it like dead veins; tight, silent, and probably riddled with sensors. But it was a way in.

To the right: a decommissioned service-bot, slumped against a drainage pipe. Its shell was buckled, but its core processor casing looked intact. If she could hotwire the boot kernel… she might just wake it up loud enough to pull every merc off their route.

Ash glanced back toward the fog, then toward the door.
Quiet or loud. Thread the needle or break it wide open.

But standing still wasn’t survival.

passages.name: Choices (Scene 5)
passages.text:
(if: $ChooseNext is "Alleys")[
Ash leaned in, watching the anomalies resolve into something deliberate; repeating gaps in surveillance, always centered around the same quadrant of the Arcadia District. Always the same fifteen-minute blackout. A routine.

She pulled up the presence data and overlaid personnel logs from the same windows. One name appeared three times; Jackson Rell. Former field intel. Tactical liaison. One-time friend. Now? Unaccounted for, just like the footage.

Her fingers hovered over the display as Cipher watched her. “That look in your eye,” he said. “You just found someone to hunt.”

"And I know exactly where to look," she replied.

Moments later, the system went dark behind her. She was already gone.

[[Continue->Dark Alleys (Scene 6)]]
]

(else-if: $ChooseNext is "TurnMyselfIn")[
Ash stood alone outside the flickering haze of the dead zone, Ramon’s words still echoing in her head. Jackson Rell. Arcadia. Henshaw murder; his trail hadn’t gone cold; but her instincts were frayed, her options thin.

She looked out over the city skyline, neon streaks reflecting in puddles like lies dressed in color. Running had only buried her deeper. Maybe if she stopped; if she faced it head-on; someone in the system would still listen.

She pulled out her comm, stared at the screen for a long second, then tapped the emergency line.

“I need to speak to Chief Renna. It’s Ash Virelli. I’m turning myself in.”

[[Continue->TurnMyselfIn]]
]

passages.name: TurnMyselfIn
passages.text:
The precinct was colder than she remembered.

Glass walls. White floors. Surveillance nodes embedded in every corner. No one made eye contact; not even the officers she’d trained alongside.

The cuffs tightened when she shifted in her chair.

Across the table sat Chief Renna; older, wearier, his eyes dulled by years of policy briefs and loyalty scores.

“You did the right thing reporting in,” he said. But his voice didn’t carry it.

Ash leaned forward. “I didn’t kill Henshaw. I was set up. I have access logs, security anomalies. Jackson Rell was at the scene.”

Renna didn’t blink. “Compliance has already reviewed the packet. Every node. Every timestamp.”

Ash frowned. “You escalated this to Compliance?”

“They flagged the event before I even saw the file,” he said quietly. “Said it matched internal threat profiles.”

Her chest tightened. The case hadn’t been assigned to OmniCore’s Investigations Bureau. It had gone straight to Internal Systems Correction.

She was never meant to be cleared.

The door hissed open behind her.

Two agents entered; immaculate synthweave suits, badges bearing the insignia of OmniCore’s Correctional Oversight Division. One placed a sealed black folder on the table. The other sat across from her, eyes unreadable.

“We’ve concluded our inquiry,” the woman said. Her tone was practiced. Painless. “Your deviation falls under Clause 7: internal disruption and breach of cognitive alignment protocols.”

Ash stiffened. “What the hell does that even mean?”

“You triggered destabilizing patterns within OmniCore’s operational logic net. The evidence you submitted meets the threshold for containment. Appeal is not available once a correctional event is in progress.”

Chief Renna didn’t look up.

The agent smiled; efficient, not cruel. “Thank you for your service.”

Ash’s hands curled into fists against the table. The air felt thinner. The walls hadn’t moved, but they felt closer.

Somewhere behind the one-way glass, Detective Mendez stood silent, fists clenched at his sides, as two internal agents redirected his access credentials and escorted him down a separate corridor.

No gunfire. No breakout.

Just silence.

The truth was never contested. It was simply absorbed.

And Ash was erased with it.

Her record was marked for internal reassignment. Her designation folded into OmniCore’s architecture like a discarded thread. No public termination notice. No trial. Just protocol. Just another ghost in the machine.

YOU CHOSE THE SHORTEST POSSIBLE PATH. LIKE, BY A LONG SHOT. TURN YOURSELF IN? WHO DOES THAT? - BETTER LUCK NEXT TIME.

passages.name: Grim Road (Scene 7)
passages.text:
Ash held his gaze a moment longer, parsing the lines in his face; truth, fear, maybe even regret. Whatever part Jackson had played, this lead felt real. And if Holloway’s name was on his lips, it meant the rot wasn’t just close; it was blooming at the core.

She turned without a word, coat catching the wind like a trailing shadow.

She didn’t look back.

Holloway.
A name wrapped in polished teeth and corporate immunity. But it wasn’t just the name.

It was what came with it: Helix.

The whisper still echoed in her skull, jagged and unfinished. She needed more than rumors. She needed a keyhole into the thing they buried; and into whoever tried to bury her alongside it.

Jackson’s warning looped in her mind:
Don’t expect anyone else to talk.
Fine. She didn’t need voices. She needed servers.

By the time the city lights gave way to rusted overpasses and power-line skeletons, Ash had already charted her route. A shard of memory blinked to life - Silo Three.

Once a data relay hub on the edge of Arcadia’s jurisdiction. Quiet. Officially offline. Unofficially… maybe not.

She moved like smoke through the barricades, the first drops of rain falling again; soft, steady, like the city was trying to wash itself clean.

It was too late for that.

[[Continue->Crossfire at Silo Three (Scene 8)]]

passages.name: Echoes of Fire (Scene 18)
passages.text:
Gunfire cracked through the fog as the service bot finally collapsed, its chassis sparking against the concrete. The diversion worked; just not for long. Confusion had turned to pursuit.

Ash moved low and fast, ghosting between pillars and scrap piles as the mercs thundered past. She slipped through the freight entrance just before the last one doubled back, her breath sharp in her throat.

Inside, the air shifted. Cooler. Controlled. The silo wasn’t abandoned.

It was archived.

Blue auxiliary lights pulsed beneath the floor panels like a sleeping heartbeat. Towering machines slumbered in shadow; old servers, cryo racks, mothballed drones arranged like a failed dream museum.

Ash crept across a narrow catwalk, boots silent on the grate. Below, in the command bay, something moved.

A lone guard stood at a flickering console, muttering into his comms; tone clipped, nervous. Not standard patrol cadence.

She caught pieces:

“Directive revision… project Helix… execute containment… asset compromised...”
Ash’s pulse spiked. Helix. Again.

She scanned the room. No backup. Just him. And maybe a backdoor into something bigger.

She weighed her options.

Take him down; fast, surgical, extract what she could before alarms lit up.

Or vanish. Stay ahead of the sweep. Live to chase another lead.

But that meant walking out with empty hands.

Again.

And the window was closing.

  (goto: "Choices (Scene 18)")
]

(link: "Escape empty-handed.")[

  (goto: "Choices (Scene 18)")
]

passages.name: Cryo Relic (Scene 9)
passages.text:
The duct dropped into a narrow crawlspace above a chamber still humming with power. Pale blue lights pulsed softly from aging equipment racks, casting long shadows over frost-lined floors. Cold vapor hissed from cracked coolant lines, curling around Ash’s boots like smoke.

This wasn’t abandoned. This was preserved.

Ash dropped down silently, her boots landing between stacks of obsolete servers sealed in cryo-stasis. OmniCore logos; faded but unmistakable; were etched into every panel. Data relics. Prototype systems. She passed a wall of dormant surveillance units, still shaped like the city’s first wave of street drones.

Then her eyes caught it: a terminal lit by auxiliary power, its interface glitching through a degraded login loop.

She keyed into the root directory manually, fingers moving on instinct. No network. No tether. But local storage was still intact.

Directory structure: encrypted logs, internal comms, asset transfers. Most of it corrupted or deliberately wiped. But not all.

One file surfaced, halfway through a scrub cycle. "`PRJ-HLX_BetaLog-Override.msg`”

Ash opened it. Partially corrupted. Fragmented headers. But enough remained.

“…inconsistencies observed in timestamp alignment across segment 7A logs. Attribution flagged to inactive field asset Virelli. Holloway directive permits override; no audit required at this stage. Maintain compartmentalization.”

Her pulse quickened.

This was it; proof, not whispers. Not fear-wrapped names or half-burned rumors.
Holloway’s override. Her name in the log. The cover-up laid bare.

No wonder the guards weren’t patrolling this route. They never thought anyone would get in this way.

And if they found out she had? They’d burn everything.

She backed out of the interface and surveyed the rest of the chamber. If this place stayed standing, OmniCore would come back. Maybe not today, but eventually. They’d finish the wipe. Burn it all.

Time to make a choice.

(link: "I need to download the raw drives and get out of here.")[
  (set: $CryoChoice to "FileDownload")
  (goto: "Choices (Scene 9)")
]

(link: "This place is too dangerous. It's time to get rid of it once and for all.")[
  (set: $CryoChoice to "Explosives")
  (goto: "Choices (Scene 9)")
]

passages.name: Choices (Scene 9)
passages.text:
(if: $CryoChoice is "FileDownload")[
Ash quickly connected her portable drive, watching anxiously as the data streamed across in pulses of blue. Her fingers tapped impatiently on the terminal, eyes flicking constantly to the entryway. Every second felt stretched, every pulse like a heartbeat in the darkness.

When the transfer finally completed, she ripped the drive from the port and pocketed it securely. No alarms yet. But time was slipping away.

Ash climbed swiftly back into the duct, retracing her steps in silence. As she emerged outside into the night’s cold embrace, rain greeted her like an old adversary. She didn’t pause to breathe until she was blocks away, blending effortlessly into the city's anonymous neon blur.

Now she had the evidence; she just needed someone she could trust.
[[Continue->Back-Channel (Scene 10)]]
]

(else-if: $CryoChoice is "Explosives")[
Ash backed away from the terminal, bile rising in her throat. The data was damning; but incomplete. Half-buried. Fragile. And if she carried it out, every scanner between here and the outer loop would light her up like a flare.

No. Letting this place stand was too dangerous.

She scanned the chamber again; every corner, every sealed access panel. That’s when she spotted it: a locked utility cage in the far corner, its mesh door bent inward like someone had tried to force it and given up halfway.

She pried it open.

Inside: a rusted OmniCore emergency cache. Security-standard breaching charges. Three of them. Designed for doors; but powerful enough to wreck cryo racks. Probably left behind when the silo was shut down in a hurry. Their seals were dusty but intact.

Ash crouched and activated each one, the LEDs blinking from red to amber as she synced the timers manually. No remote detonation. Old school.

Her hands moved on instinct; planting the charges at structural choke points, between coolant tanks and data stacks. She double-checked the timers. Ninety seconds.

She took one last look at the blinking terminal and the icy archive shelves around her. If she left it intact, someone else might finish what Holloway started. And this time, they’d erase her completely.

Ash climbed back into the duct, heart thudding. The countdown echoed in her mind with every motion.

Thirty seconds.

Should be enough time.
[[Continue->Collateral (END B-)*]]
]

She pried it open.

Inside: a rusted OmniCore emergency cache. Security-standard breaching charges. Three of them. Designed for doors; but powerful enough to wreck cryo racks. Probably left behind when the silo was shut down in a hurry. Their seals were dusty but intact.

Ash crouched and activated each one, the LEDs blinking from red to amber as she synced the timers manually. No remote detonation. Old school.

Her hands moved on instinct; planting the charges at structural choke points, between coolant tanks and data stacks. She double-checked the timers. Ninety seconds.

She took one last look at the blinking terminal and the icy archive shelves around her. If she left it intact, someone else might finish what Holloway started. And this time, they’d erase her completely.

Ash climbed back into the duct, heart thudding. The countdown echoed in her mind with every motion.

Thirty seconds.

Should be enough time.
[[Continue->Collateral (END B-)*]]

passages.name: Back-Channel (Scene 10)
passages.text:
The back-channel café was a whisper tucked beneath a freight line; half-forgotten, half-invented, and entirely off the books. Neon from the pawn shop across the alley painted blood-red streaks across the rain-slicked glass. Ash slipped through the door and let it seal behind her with a pneumatic hiss.

No eyes. No tech. Just silence, shadows, and the promise of deniability.

Mendez sat in the far booth, nursing something too dark to be coffee. He didn’t look up when she approached; just said, “Took you long enough.”

Ash didn’t sit. “You’re lucky I came at all.”

“No Riley?” he asked, eyebrow raised. “Figured he’d still be stuck to your side.”

Ash’s eyes flicked up, sharp. “He was there this morning. Said all the right things. After this mess? He’s probably keeping his distance. Can’t say I blame him - at least he has an excuse.”

Now Mendez looked up, face drawn, rainlight carving shadows under his eyes. “You think I had a choice?”

“You were at my door before sunrise. With half the precinct behind you.”

“Exactly,” he said. “Zero-hour flag. Came straight from upstairs. No appeal. No time. If I hadn’t gone, someone else would’ve, and you wouldn’t have had the head start.”

He paused. “I wanted you to run.”

Ash narrowed her eyes, watching for cracks in his voice. There weren’t any.

“So this is you making it right?” she asked.

“This is me giving you the chance to do something with what you found.”

Ash tilted her head. “You don’t know what I found.”

“I know where you went. We’ve all heard rumors about Silo Three.” He tapped the side of his cup. “Some kind of experimental subproject. Off-ledger.”

Ash didn’t answer right away. She slid into the booth across from him, movements deliberate. Then she spoke, low and careful.

“I saw fragments. System logs. Protocol overrides. Holloway’s signature stamped across every layer.”

A pause.

“And a name: Helix.”

Mendez went still. His fingers froze mid-drum on the cup. “…Helix? I’ve heard that name; buried in old chatter, like a ghost file no one wanted to admit existed.”

Ash didn’t flinch. “It seems you know more than most.”

“No,” he said quietly. “Just enough to know it scared the right people.”

Ash turned toward the window. Rain whispered down the glass like a clock counting backward.

“They’re not cleaning house,” she said. “They’re rewriting it.”

Mendez nodded slowly. “Then you need to move. If you’ve got anything, Cipher can help. But it has to stay offline.”

Ash studied him. Silence stretched. “So is this the part where you ask me if I brought the evidence?”

He didn’t blink. “No. This is the part where I hope you trust me enough to say yes.”

]

(link: "Keep the drive to yourself; safer not to trust anyone, not yet.")[

passages.name: Collateral (END B-)*
passages.text:
She cleared the hatch with seconds to spare.

Then... IMPACT.

The blast ripped through the silo like a thunderclap, flattening the upper structure in a storm of steel and fire. Heat rolled across the ground in a breathless wave, chasing Ash as she dove behind a ruined barricade. The earth trembled beneath her.

When the smoke finally thinned, only a crater remained. Silo Three was gone; along with the servers, the proof, and any path toward redemption.

Ash coughed, forcing herself upright. Her muscles ached. Her ribs screamed. But she was alive.

No evidence. No trail. Just a growing silence and the weight of knowing she'd erased the only real leverage she had.

The war wasn't over. But her piece of the battlefield had just burned to ash.

Ash survived the blast, but the truth dies with the data. She remains a fugitive; without proof, without allies, and without a way back.

But somewhere in the rubble, a fragment of the data‑core still blinked; waiting for anyone stubborn enough to dig.

Ash didn’t get far.

The blast still echoed behind her when the whine of a surveillance drone cut through the rain. She turned toward the sound; hands raised, no weapon drawn.

A single shot cracked the silence.

No warning. No arrest.

Just protocol.

ASH DIED, UNABLE TO CLEAR HER NAME.

passages.text:
(if: $EnterOrRun is "LoneGuard")[
Ash steadied her breath. If this guard had eyes on Project Helix, he wasn’t just muscle; he was a living thread in the conspiracy.

She edged along the catwalk, knees soft, motion silent. Below, the guard’s voice murmured into his comms; unaware, oblivious. If she waited, the window would close. If she rushed, it could light the whole silo.

She moved.

Ash dropped like a blade from the shadows; arm locked around his throat, palm smothering sound. He thrashed hard; panic and training colliding; but she didn’t give him time to choose. A twist. A choke.

Then silence.

Not dead. Just out cold.

She dragged him behind a rack of cryo hardware, heart still hammering. His ID badge blinked faint blue. She pulled it, checked the registry chip.

Time to open this thread.

[[Continue->Lone Guard (Scene 11)]]
]


(else-if: $EnterOrRun is "EmptyHanded")[
Ash froze behind the railing, watching the guard’s pattern shift. He was getting twitchy. The moment was slipping.

One move now; and the whole place would light up.

She exhaled through her nose, backing into the corridor’s edge. Tactical retreat. Not defeat.

Not yet.

This wasn’t surrender. This was preservation. The silo had served its purpose; it told her where the heat lived. Now she needed time. And a clean line to the only person who could help her find the source code beneath the smear job.

**Mendez.**

As the last pulse of blue light faded behind her, Ash vanished into the dark.

[[Continue->Shadow Exit (Scene 24)]]
]

passages.name: Lone Guard (Scene 11)
passages.text:
The guard groaned, barely conscious, as Ash knelt beside him. She moved fast; flex strap around his wrists, boots scuffing quietly as she dragged him deeper into shadow under the catwalk.

Her flashlight flicked on, filtered red. His name patch: Keene.
His ID: active OmniCore credential, Tier 4. Higher than grunt level.

That meant access.

She gave him a sharp tap across the face. “Keene. Stay with me.”

His eyes fluttered open. Bleary. Scared. But not stupid.

“You scream,” Ash said evenly, “you get a bullet. You move wrong? Same result.”

Keene nodded, jaw tight.

“Project Helix,” she said. “Talk.”

His pupils dilated. Panic now; like someone had said the word cancer.

“I... I just reroute logistics,” he stammered. “I don't handle it direct. I only saw fragments. Orders rerouted. Protocol overrides. Ghost tags.”

“Who gave the override?”

He hesitated. Ash pressed a knee into his chest; not hard. Just enough to promise escalation.

“Someone bypassed the review stack,” he gasped. “Accessed the BetaLog manually. It shouldn’t even exist; it was flagged for archive deletion cycles ago.”

Ash’s voice sharpened. “Where is it?”

“Cold rack,” Keene wheezed. “Sub-core level. Red zone. No uplink. Air-gapped. It’s legacy format only.”

That matched what she remembered from the old schematics. She hauled him upright. “Show me.”

They moved through a narrow stairwell into the lower levels. The glow here was sterile; low light from emergency backups, casting the gear in sickly blues and reds.

Cryo data bays. Decommissioned drone specs. Hazard-taped mesh-net experiments.

It felt like walking through an abandoned operating room.

Keene stopped at a sealed cabinet wired to local power. “This is it.”

Ash popped the latch and slid the panel open. The drive array was warm. Active.

One by one, she pulled the data cores; each labeled with scrub-cycle timestamps and black-marker tags.

Then, behind a thermal shield plate:
PRJ-HLX_BetaLog-Override.msg

She slotted it into her portable decryptor. The interface blinked amber. Processing...

Keene stared at the floor, breath shaky. “They wiped upstream. This rack’s off-ledger. They think it’s dead.”

“You’re going to forget this moment,” Ash said flatly. “If I find your name in a report; ”

“I won’t,” he interrupted, voice breaking. “You think I want to get ghosted over this?”

The decryptor pinged.

Transfer complete.

Ash slid the core into her coat and stepped back. Keene slumped to the floor without another word.

She took a service duct out; quiet, tight, clean.

Rain hit her face the moment she emerged. Cold. Familiar.

She didn’t stop moving until the silo had vanished behind towers of broken neon.

Ash reached into her coat, pulled a microline transmitter, and keyed a number from memory.

Two rings.

“Mendez,” came the voice.

“We need to meet,” she said.

A pause.

“Same place as before.”

Ash hung up.

[[Continue->Back-Channel (Scene 10)]]

passages.name: Choices (Scene 10)
passages.text:
(if: $MendezChoice is "MendezFile")[
Ash reached into her coat, fingers brushing the edge of the drive. It wasn’t trust; just strategy with a pulse.

She slid the device across the table. Mendez took it carefully, his thumb grazing the edge like it might bite.

“This doesn’t leave the room,” she said.

“It won’t,” he answered, calm but low.

A moment passed; and then a voice drifted from deeper inside the café:

“Well, that’s my cue.”

Cipher stepped out from the shadows of the back room, a compact rig already booted in his arms. His hoodie was half-zipped, eyes sharp and unreadable. “Let’s see what flavor of corporate nightmare we’re working with.”

Ash leaned back in her seat, the drive out of her hands now. The weight hadn’t vanished. Just shifted.

[[Continue->City on Edge (Scene 13)]]
]

(else-if: $MendezChoice is "TrustNoOne")[
Ash’s hand hovered over her coat pocket. She didn’t move.

“I didn’t bring anything,” she said.

Mendez didn’t call her bluff. Just stared; quiet, steady.

A beat passed.

From the shadows beyond the bar, a voice cut through: “Then what’s the glowing guilt-chip in your jacket?”

Ash didn’t flinch.

Cipher stepped out from the back, arms crossed, rig already powered and humming. “I’ve been listening since you walked in. Figured we’d get here eventually.”

Ash pulled the drive from her coat and placed it on the table like a challenge.

“I lied,” she said. “But I didn’t walk in here for the hospitality.”

Cipher gave her a crooked grin and dropped the rig on the table. “Good. Because this place ran out of that three regimes ago.”

[[Continue->City on Edge (Scene 13)]]
]

passages.name: City on Edge (Scene 13)
passages.text:
The café lights dimmed as Cipher activated the rig, its bootloader humming with low, ionized tension. Holograms flickered to life; fractured directories, encrypted logs, half-corrupted permissions bleeding static across the interface.

Ash leaned in as the data slowly unraveled. Not clean. Not whole. But enough.

“PRJ-HLX_BetaLog,” Cipher muttered. “Fragmented... overwritten in parts. But there’s still a core signature.”

Lines of scrambled code poured past. Mendez stood behind him, silent, eyes locked on the screen.

“Someone went through a lot of effort to erase this. But not well enough.”
Then the file structure hiccuped; glitched; and resumed. A redacted string stuttered into view, pixelated and sharp:

//Directive active: Helix//
//Asset Virelli ; status: COMPROMISED//
//Surveillance rerouted. Clearance suspended. Tracking priority elevated.//

Ash stiffened. Her name; tagged, traced, hunted. But no details. No cause. Just cold execution logic.

Cipher zoomed in, scrolling deeper through the corrupted metadata. “This isn’t just a protocol. It’s persistent. Autonomous. And still live.”

“Helix was supposed to be a ghost project,” Mendez said quietly. “Old rumor. Top floor fiction.”

“It’s not fiction,” Ash replied. Her voice was calm, but her hands were fists.

“No,” Cipher agreed. “It’s a black-budget AI scaffold. Aggressive learning model. Off-ledger deployments. And someone let it off the leash.”

Ash stared at the final string, still blinking at the bottom of the log:

//Containment failed. Rerouting active assets. Field response pending.//

“They’re still using it,” she said. “Or it’s using them.”

passages.name: Path to Ramon
passages.text:
Ash stepped out into the rain-soaked alley behind Cipher’s safehouse, pulling her collar high against the cold. The city felt closer now; its metal lungs hissing, neon eyes watching. She walked fast, aimless at first, unsure whether to disappear or dig deeper.

Her comm pinged.

The tone was analog; low fidelity, off-grid. A backdoor frequency only a handful of people still knew.

Ash slipped into a recessed doorway and checked the signal. It was a single line of text, unencrypted but unmistakably Ramon’s style:

//Got something you’ll want. Face to face. Same ladder, different floor. –R//

Her fingers hovered over the reply pad, then closed the device instead. Ramon wasn’t the type to chase ghosts. If he was reaching out, it meant something real.

Ash slipped back into the current of the city, head down, pulse steady.

passages.text:
(if: $FileChoice is "BlastFiles")[
Ash stood still for a long moment, staring at the decrypted files pulsing faintly on the rig; raw, damning, irreversible.

“This doesn’t wait,” she said. “No redlines, no backroom trades. We dump it now.”

Cipher hesitated. “Once it hits the stream, it’s everywhere. No edits. No shields.”

“I know,” Ash replied. “It’s my name on half those logs. If anyone’s going to burn for this, it should be my choice.”

Mendez gave a small nod, grim but steady.

Cipher’s fingers hovered, then moved.

The upload initiated; silent, fast, final.

Ash didn’t look away.

[[Continue->White-box War Room (Scene 14)]]
]


(else-if: $FileChoice is "StealHelix")[
“If we’re doing this,” Ash said, voice low and steady, “we’re doing it right. Let's get everything we can first.”

Cipher nodded and sealed the drive into cold storage, a flicker of blue static dancing across the containment rig. No leaks. No alarms. Not yet.

Ash exhaled slowly, the decision pressing down like gravity. "We have to bury Holloway with her own monster.”

Mendez crossed his arms, gaze fixed on the dimmed display. “She’ll know we’re close. That kind of signal doesn’t go unnoticed.”

Cipher’s expression hardened. “Then we move fast; before the board rewrites history.”

Outside, the city wailed beneath corporate silence. Inside the bunker: only the quiet hum of commitment.

[[Continue->Silent Calculus (Scene 15)]]
]

passages.name: White-box War Room (Scene 14)
passages.text:
A hush settled in the café as Cipher confirmed the upload had gone live. For a long minute, nothing happened. Then news feeds on the holopad began to flash:

//SECURITY BREACH AT OMNICORE ; CLASSIFIED FILES LEAKED//

A half-dozen independent bloggers started streaming, piecing together fragments; nobody had the whole picture, but the word “Helix” was already leaking out.

Cipher pulled up a wireframe of OmniCore’s network, watching for the first signs of counterattack. “Nothing yet. No takedowns, no blocks. Either they’re scrambling, or they’re about to clamp down; hard.”

Mendez paced, tension radiating off him. “Holloway won’t wait long. As soon as she’s got a story, she’ll run it citywide.”

The holopad pinged. An internal OmniCore alert had slipped into the public stream; an accident, or a warning.

Cipher zoomed in on the network map. “Sub-Level Sigma. That’s where the core Helix firmware’s still dark. If we want real leverage, we pull the code itself; proof that can’t be spun.”

Mendez’s phone vibrated. He checked it, then frowned, showing Ash the display. “Riley’s precinct login just pinged the Southgrid relay. First activity since the raid.”

He met her eyes. “Could be bait. Or he could be trying to help.”

Ash took a breath. Sirens still sounded in the distance; uncertain, not yet a storm. The city hadn’t erupted, not yet. But it would.

They looked at her; waiting for the next move.

passages.name: Silent Calculus (Scene 15)
passages.text:
The café was silent now, lit only by the soft white glow of Cipher’s projection map.

Ash stood before it, arms folded, every node and trace route burned into her mind like constellations in a war sky. Across the city, chaos simmered beneath the surface. Typical. Feeds buzzed with speculation, OmniCore clamped down, and yet… no one knew the truth. Not yet.

Behind her, the drive sat frozen in Cipher’s deep-stack vault, locked in a temperature-controlled shell surrounded by shielding foam and old promise.

Cipher walked over, calling up the live network scan. “Sub-Level Sigma,” he said, zooming into a hidden node beneath OmniCore’s central tower. “It’s where they compile and sign every Helix payload. Secure shell. Internal drones. No surface signal.”

“Getting in?” Mendez asked.

“Insane,” Cipher replied. “But not impossible.”

Ash narrowed her eyes. The Sigma vault was the killshot. If they could extract live firmware logs; signed, timestamped, unspinnable; they could collapse Holloway’s entire shadow empire.

Then Mendez's tablet chirped.

He glanced down. Blinked. “You’re not gonna like this.”

He swiped to cast the data onto the wall: a signal trace, shallow but real; an OmniCore precinct login tagged to Riley. Active. Southgrid node. Twenty minutes ago.

“Could be him,” Mendez said. “Could be bait. Either way… it’s the first real noise he’s made since the raid.”

Ash’s jaw tensed. The last time she saw Riley, he was caught between orders and regret, and she was running for her life. But she trusted him. He had always been there for her.

“His access codes might still work,” Mendez said. “He could walk us through Sigma's front door.”

Cipher glanced between them and gave a half-shrug. “Unless it’s a trap,” he muttered, more out of habit than conviction.

Mendez rolled his eyes. “It’s Riley. If he’s signaling us, it’s not to sell her more lies.”

The bunker hummed around them, quiet but charged; like the city above, waiting to tip.

Ash stepped forward, fingertips brushing the glass overlay as the two paths glowed faintly beneath her touch; one buried in steel and systems, the other veiled in shadows and memories.

Two ways in. No way back.

passages.name: Choices (Scene 14 & 15)
passages.text:
(if: $SubLevelChoice is "Infiltrate")[
Ash pulled her hand away from the display, eyes locking on the pulsing Sigma node like a demolition target. “Then we cut straight to the root,” she said. “No more smoke. No more shields. We’re infiltrating Sub-Level Sigma.”

Cipher was already queuing breach schematics, hands flickering across the interface.

Mendez reached for his gear, but Ash stopped him with a glance. “You can’t come with us. If this goes south, they’ll burn your badge and pin the whole thing on you.”

He hesitated, jaw tight. “Not sure I can sit this out.”

“Run comms,” she said. “Eyes on the perimeter. Feed us what you can from outside.”

Mendez nodded, frustration in the set of his shoulders. “You get what you need,” he said. “I’ve got your back.”

Whatever waited in Sigma would be signed, sealed, and fatal for anyone trying to hide it.

The quiet was gone. Time for the noise.

[[Continue->Sub-Level Sigma (Scene 16)]]
]


(else-if: $SubLevelChoice is "TraceRiley")[
Ash stared at the faint signal Riley had left behind, barely a flicker, but steady. Familiar.

“He’s trying to help,” she said softly, almost to herself. “We find him, and maybe we don’t need to burn the whole city down to bring this to light.”

Cipher nodded once, expression unreadable. Mendez holstered his sidearm, voice low. “If anyone can get us inside without tripping alarms, it’s Riley.”

Ash’s posture straightened as she watched the beacon pulse; faint, but unmistakably his.

“He always knew where the lines were,” she said quietly. “And when to cross them.”

This time, she was going to meet him on the other side.

[[Continue->Missing Partner (Scene 17)]]
]

passages.name: Missing Partner (Scene 17)
passages.text:
Southgrid had gone hollow.

No drones. No sirens. Just the low hum of flickering junction boxes and the occasional snap of rain hitting old neon. Ash moved carefully through the skeletal remains of the old OmniCore precinct; slipping past rusted floodgates, ducking beneath collapsed scaffolding, her boots echoing through alleys she once knew by heartbeat.

Mendez led them through a side alley toward the substation, its access gate chained but half-rusted through. Cipher crouched beside the lock, gave Ash a glance, and pulled a coil from his rig. A few sparks later, the chain clattered loose.

They slipped inside.

The substation was dark, save for the blinking light of a standby console deep in the basement stairwell. Ash reached the wall panel, pulled Mendez’s clearance code from memory, and keyed in the sequence. A low whirr, a hiss of shifting servos; then the hatch cracked open.

She moved first.

The air inside was sharp and dry, laced with rust and ozone. Her footfalls softened as they reached the bottom. Shelving units loomed like forgotten skeletons, and in the far corner, a jury-rigged terminal glowed faintly; cobbled together from scavenged field tech, still pulsing with narrowband power.

Ash crossed the floor, eyes narrowed.

Cipher was already beside the unit, running a diagnostic from a handheld deck. “This is clean work,” he murmured. “Not a trap. A message.”

Mendez hung back, near the door. Watching.

Ash leaned in. The screen scrolled slowly; manual uplink traces, beacon routing, and one flagged packet: a data spike bouncing from the precinct node to a location in the Arcadia District. Arcadia Tower. 26th floor.

She pulled the log up again. No other pings. No redundancies.

“This wasn’t sent in panic,” she muttered. “It’s deliberate.”

Cipher nodded. “He’s pointing us somewhere. Could be a backdoor into Sigma.”

Mendez stepped forward now, voice low. “Or a breadcrumb meant to get you out in the open. His apartment’s not far from here. If he’s still alive… you might find something real. Or at least personal.”

Ash stared at the blinking trace. It pulsed. Not frantic. Not decayed.

Steady. Intentional.

(link: "Go to his apartment and look for him. This lead feels like a trap.")[

  (goto: "Choices (Scene 17)")
]

(link: "Follow the signal. If Riley's leading you somewhere, trust the path.")[
  (set: $rileyTrust to "signal")
  (goto: "Choices (Scene 17)")
]

passages.name: Sub-Level Sigma (Scene 16)
passages.text:
Cipher was already pulling schematics, mapping their ingress route from an old freight lift buried beneath the NeoLynx utility wing. Ash moved with him, sliding her pistol into its side holster as the bunker lights dimmed behind them. No ceremony. No backup. Just a trace route into the hollowed bones of OmniCore.

Fifteen minutes later, the lift groaned to life; dust shaking loose as Ash and Cipher began their descent.

The freight lift groaned as it sank into the dark; each level peeling away the city's pulse, each meter slicing signal and sky behind them.

Ash stood still, back straight, arms slack at her sides. Not relaxed. Ready.

Beside her, Cipher adjusted the mesh-and-ion satchel cradling their breach gear. His eyes tracked the flickering panel readout above the elevator door, but his voice stayed low.

“We’re not just under NeoLynx anymore,” he muttered. “This is skin-level infrastructure. OmniCore's cortical stem. Every fiber of control flows through here.”

Ash’s gaze didn’t shift. “Then one cut might paralyze the whole body.”

The lift shuddered to a halt. A hiss of pressure. Then the doors split open; not with fanfare, but with surgical precision.

Sigma.

It felt less like a facility and more like a sealed memory. No ambient noise. No atmospheric hum. Just white corridors, seamless and sterile, stretching like arteries into silence. No visible cams. No directional lighting. Just you and whatever followed.

Mendez’s voice crackled through the tightband comm. “Perimeter’s still blind. But they’ll notice the pulse dips soon. Make it count.”

Ash and Cipher moved in sync; one fluid shape across the floor. Ahead, the central archive node pulsed faintly behind frost-laced glass. Racks of coolant-sealed drives nested into a recessed vault. Each one pulsing with the breath of a sleeping god.

This was it. The marrow of Helix. The signed firmware logs, origin timestamps, chain-of-command traces. The lie Holloway had buried; encoded and preserved.

Cipher dropped to a crouch, pulling a thin blade of data-thread from the satchel. “One slice,” he whispered, “and we’re inside its spinal cord.”

Ash approached the main interface panel. Her fingers hovered just above the surface, feeling the hum beneath the casing. Alive. A quiet predator coiled behind carbon glass.

She exhaled slowly, each breath slicing the tension into manageable pieces.

“We don’t cage it this time,” she said. “We expose it.”

A beat. Then she pressed her palm to the glass.

The lights dipped. The silence cracked.

It had begun.

passages.name: Choices (Scene 17)
passages.text:
(if: $rileyTrust is "personal")[
Ash stepped back from the terminal, eyes fixed on the beacon’s slow, steady blink. 

“It’s pointing to Arcadia,” she said, voice low. “But Riley wouldn’t drop a trace like this unless he wanted me to find it. And if he’s trying to finish something, he wouldn’t leave without covering his back.”

She turned away from the screen. “I want to check in on his place first before I trust this breadcrumb.”

Cipher gave a quiet nod. Mendez keyed in the metro route on his wristpad, the display flickering to life.

Ash adjusted her collar, slipping into the rhythm of movement again.

This time, she wasn’t hoping for answers. She was ready to demand them.

[[Continue->Riley’s Apartment (Scene 20)]]
]

(else-if: $rileyTrust is "signal")[
Ash stared at the blinking signal; faint, deliberate. A single breadcrumb in a field of ash.

She rose slowly, her expression sharpening into something between belief and calculation. “This isn’t a cry for help. It’s a route.”

Cipher zipped the terminal kit closed. “Arcadia Tower’s locked down six ways past impossible.”

Ash nodded. “Then we find the door they didn’t bolt. He left this signal for a reason and I don’t think it ends at the 26th floor.”

She paused at the stairwell, rain still tapping faintly on the broken vents above.

And if she was wrong?

She didn’t say it out loud. She just moved.

[[Continue->Arcadia Tower 26 (Scene 21)]]
]

passages.name: Riley’s Apartment (Scene 20)
passages.text:
The elevator rose in smooth silence, its shielding hum the only sound between them. Ash stood near the front, gaze fixed on the changing floor numbers. Cipher checked his rig idly. Mendez stood beside the door, unusually still.

Riley’s building was quiet; too quiet for Coregate-adjacent. No guards. No ID scanners. Just a private key panel and architecture that whispered discretion.

They reached the 42nd floor.

The hallway was crisp, expensive without being showy. Doors spaced evenly, carpet clean. No signs of panic or disorder. Just calm.

Ash approached Apartment 426 and scanned the entry pad.

Unlocked.

She exchanged a glance with Mendez, then pushed the door open.

Inside, everything was still.

Not abandoned. Just... paused.

The furniture was minimal but curated. Neutral tones. High-end coffee gear still powered on in the kitchen. A jacket draped neatly over a wall hook. This wasn’t someone on the run.

It was someone mid-decision.

Ash moved first, tracing a slow circle around the main room. Cipher followed, scanning with a micro-wand. “No heat signatures. Someone came and went recently; hour, maybe less.”

Ash reached the glass desk. A cracked OmniCore badge sat next to a stripped burner node. Nearby, a napkin from a corner café; scrawled with a name and a floor:

ARCADIA - FL26

Her breath caught. “Same floor the beacon was pointing to.”

Cipher crouched near a vent under the desk, ears tilting toward a subtle hum. “Something’s active.”

He peeled the panel away. Inside, wrapped in anti-static cloth, was a slim black data disc.

On the casing, scrawled in permanent marker:

//FOR A.//

Ash took it slowly, her jaw set tight.

(set: $hasDisc to true)

Cipher scanned it immediately. “Partial logs. Encrypted voice data. Metadata’s intact; Riley tagged this personally. Could be the why behind all of this.”

Mendez stepped beside her, brow furrowed. “If he’s in Arcadia Tower, we don’t wait. We go now.”

Ash turned to him, the disc still in hand.

“You don’t go,” she said quietly.

He blinked. “What?”

“You’re still official. If they catch us and you’re there, it won’t just be a fallout; it’ll be your badge, your life. They’ll make you the traitor.”

“I’m not letting you go in alone.”

“You won’t be,” she said. “You’ll run comms. Feed us floor plans, traffic spikes, patrol routes. From outside, you’re an asset. Inside? You’re a liability.”

Mendez didn’t argue right away.

Then, with a clipped nod: “You better come back with something that matters.”

Ash pocketed the disc, folding the napkin carefully beside it.

“Plan’s changing,” she said. “But the direction stays the same.”

She turned for the elevator.

Next stop; Arcadia Tower.

[[Continue->Arcadia Tower 26 (Scene 21)]]

passages.name: Arcadia Tower 26 (Scene 21)
passages.text:
The service ladder rattled under Ash’s grip as she climbed, boots scraping metal with each quiet pull upward. Twenty-six stories below, Arcadia’s sprawl glimmered like circuitry; alive, oblivious. Up here, the air was thin, the wind taut with static.

Cipher moved just ahead, his lean frame silhouetted against the glowing underbelly of Arcadia Tower. “Elevator shafts are too hot,” he said over his shoulder. “Drone net’s throttled at this hour, but still twitchy.”

Ash nodded once, following him up the last few rungs. She paused just shy of the ledge, scanning the skyline. Arcadia Tower rose above them; chrome, obsidian, faceless. It didn’t reflect the city. It erased it.

They climbed onto the 26th floor’s maintenance catwalk, circling around until they reached the exterior access hatch. Cipher worked the manual lock. Ash kept watch, eyes darting to the beacon trace on her wristband. Riley’s signal had ended here. Floor 26. Tied to a rooftop directional uplink node; routed, oddly, from a civilian net.

The hatch creaked open, revealing an exposed platform used for antenna maintenance. 

Cipher moved first, crouching beside the uplink dish at the edge of the platform. “Something was fired off from here. Burst packet.”

Ash stepped carefully across the grating. The beacon node was still warm; recently triggered. She crouched beside it, fingers brushing a loose vent cover. Inside: an OmniCore badge, standard issue.

Riley’s.

She held it in her palm, frowning. It was clean. Too clean.

Mendez’s voice crackled over comms. “Just got a net trace. That burst hit three nodes; OmniCore archive mirror, Helix firmware ghost, and some off-grid relay tucked under Harbor Sector. Looks like your boy’s scattering breadcrumbs.”

Cipher ran a fast trace on the data node. “Tag on the final packet points underground. Something called Harbor-12.”

Ash stood, staring past the dish toward the endless sprawl. The wind tugged at her coat.

She turned to Cipher. “What’s the best way into Harbor?”

He gave a faint grin. “We follow the freight line. Quiet ride. Fewer questions.”

Ash nodded, already stepping back toward the ladder. As they descended into the dark, the lights of Arcadia dimmed behind them; out of reach, out of time.

Below, the city’s veins pulsed with secrets.

[[Continue → Data-Harbor Ride (Scene 22)]]

passages.name: Continue → Data-Harbor Ride (Scene 22)
passages.text:
The freight ferry groaned through knee-deep black water as Cipher piloted it around the jagged pylons of Harbor-12. Rusted shipping crates loomed like dead memories. Distant tunnel fans clicked rhythmically, blowing damp air across their skin.

Ash crouched near the bow, one hand steadying herself on a steel beam as the boat bumped gently along the rails. Ahead, the tracks curved toward a maintenance door built into the retaining wall; a structure Cipher swore hadn’t been scanned in over a decade.

“Whatever's down here, it's intentionally forgotten.”

Ash kept her eyes on the door. This was the endpoint Riley’s beacon had pointed to. Whether he’d been here or just redirected something through it, she wasn’t sure. But it was more than a signal.

(if: $hasDisc)[
Ash reached into her coat and pulled out the shielded disc they’d recovered from Riley’s apartment. It was warm now; Cipher’s rig had been running silent decryption threads since they left Arcadia.

Cipher met her glance and gave a short nod. “First log’s clean. Audio only.”

She slipped in the earpiece and leaned back against the bulkhead as the ferry sloshed beneath them.

Riley’s voice broke through; distorted by compression, but unmistakably his.

> “Ash. If you’re hearing this, I didn’t get the chance to explain; so this is what’s left. Helix wasn’t supposed to survive shutdown. But it did. And now it’s rewriting protocol, burying trails, purging operators like assets gone bad.”

> “I tried to stay out. Thought I could fix it from the margins. But I was wrong. And they’re using my silence to erase you.”

> “Harbor-12 leads below SkySpire. If you’re close, you need to see what they kept buried. Just know; Helix isn’t a weapon anymore. It’s something else, and I'm pretty sure Holloway is giving it full access tonight.”

The message cut out in a sharp burst of static.

Ash sat frozen for a long moment. Riley hadn’t just known about Helix; he’d been *inside* it. Knew what it was becoming.

Her breath caught in her throat. She thought she’d been chasing a file. A cover-up. A target.

Now she wasn’t sure what she was chasing anymore.

She said nothing as she slipped the disc back into her coat.

But something cold had settled under her skin.
]

The ferry coasted to a halt beside the old dock. Above it, a concrete arch framed a corroded bulkhead, the faded OmniCore logo barely visible beneath decades of grime.

Cipher killed the engine. Silence rushed in like a vacuum.

Ash stepped out first. The dock shuddered under her boots. She traced a gloved hand along the edge of the access door, where a faint mechanical hiss sounded from within. Still powered. Still functional.

Cipher checked his rig. “Service Tunnel 17B,” he confirmed. “Old elevator routing. Leads straight into SkySpire’s substructure.”

Ash nodded once, gaze locked upward. “Alright, Riley... this better be right,” she muttered to herself. 

Then Mendez’s voice cracked through comms. “Heads up. SkySpire's net just flared. Holloway’s running a private launch in the core atrium. Quiet guest list. No press. High-clearance only.”

Ash stared at Cipher resolutely. “She’s flipping the switch.”

Ash looked to the stairwell carved into the concrete beside the tunnel. No guards. No barriers. Just a path no one was supposed to remember.

“She’s flipping the switch,” Ash echoed, voice like steel. “So we pull the fuse.”

She started up the stairs, coat trailing behind her like a drawn shadow. Cipher followed close behind, steps quiet, steady.

Below them, the ferry engine clicked softly as it cooled.

Above, power was shifting.

[[Continue->Circle Tightens (Scene 24)]]
