passages.name: Circle Tightens (Scene 24)
passages.text:
The SkySpire rose like a blade into Arcadia’s haze, its mirrored surface swallowing neon and shadow alike. From the service perch three levels below the main plaza, Ash watched the base of the tower pulse with ordered movement; black-suit escorts, silent drones, and facial-scrubbed guests funneled through scanning gates.

They’d surfaced through Service Tunnel 17B; an old freight lift forgotten by most, bypassed by all. Riley’s route. The only one that hadn’t lit up the grid.

Cipher crouched beside a vent grille, scanning the plaza’s upper decks. “Gala entry’s on level 44. One lift, three choke points, and a biometric loop baked into guest credentials.”

Ash tracked a convoy of hovercars gliding into the intake zone; unmarked, tinted, expensive. “No press?”

“Zero broadcast bleed,” Cipher confirmed. “It’s a blackout. Just board execs and top brass. They’re launching Helix tonight. Quiet power transfer.”

Mendez’s voice crackled in through comms, sharp. “I traced a pulse buried under their floorplan; Subdeck Seven. Matches the access node Riley flagged. No net uplink. Closed system.”

Cipher frowned. “Can’t get visuals. But I’m pulling legacy schematics now… If this map’s right, that subdeck feeds into Helix’s local execution layer. It’s part of the control lattice.”

Ash shifted her weight, eyes narrowing. “Riley’s down there?”

“Could be,” Mendez said. “Or something tied to his ID. Either way, Holloway’s running Helix through that node.”

Cipher looked up. “If he’s in that room, she’s not just detaining him. She’s using him.”

Ash didn’t answer. Just watched the tower hum under a thin mist of rain.

They had one shot; to fracture the system before Holloway sealed it. A loud confrontation or a quiet cut. Both carried risk. Both needed to land.

"Sublevel egress is tight, but it'll get us beneath the gala. From there, we branch; top or bottom. Pressure and proof.” Cipher chimed.

Ash turned toward the maintenance shaft door, rain slicking her coat like shadowed armor.

It was time to pick the fuse.

[[Continue->Gala of Glass (Scene 25)]]
passages.cleanText:
The SkySpire rose like a blade into Arcadia’s haze, its mirrored surface swallowing neon and shadow alike. From the service perch three levels below the main plaza, Ash watched the base of the tower pulse with ordered movement; black-suit escorts, silent drones, and facial-scrubbed guests funneled through scanning gates.

They’d surfaced through Service Tunnel 17B; an old freight lift forgotten by most, bypassed by all. Riley’s route. The only one that hadn’t lit up the grid.

Cipher crouched beside a vent grille, scanning the plaza’s upper decks. “Gala entry’s on level 44. One lift, three choke points, and a biometric loop baked into guest credentials.”

Ash tracked a convoy of hovercars gliding into the intake zone; unmarked, tinted, expensive. “No press?”

“Zero broadcast bleed,” Cipher confirmed. “It’s a blackout. Just board execs and top brass. They’re launching Helix tonight. Quiet power transfer.”

Mendez’s voice crackled in through comms, sharp. “I traced a pulse buried under their floorplan; Subdeck Seven. Matches the access node Riley flagged. No net uplink. Closed system.”

Cipher frowned. “Can’t get visuals. But I’m pulling legacy schematics now… If this map’s right, that subdeck feeds into Helix’s local execution layer. It’s part of the control lattice.”

Ash shifted her weight, eyes narrowing. “Riley’s down there?”

“Could be,” Mendez said. “Or something tied to his ID. Either way, Holloway’s running Helix through that node.”

Cipher looked up. “If he’s in that room, she’s not just detaining him. She’s using him.”

Ash didn’t answer. Just watched the tower hum under a thin mist of rain.

They had one shot; to fracture the system before Holloway sealed it. A loud confrontation or a quiet cut. Both carried risk. Both needed to land.

"Sublevel egress is tight, but it'll get us beneath the gala. From there, we branch; top or bottom. Pressure and proof.” Cipher chimed.

Ash turned toward the maintenance shaft door, rain slicking her coat like shadowed armor.

It was time to pick the fuse.

passages.name: Gala of Glass (Scene 25)
passages.text:
The SkySpire interior was nothing like the rest of the city.

Where Arcadia pulsed with noise and corrosion, this place whispered in glass and authority. Light slid like mercury along obsidian walls. Suspended walkways curled between atrium tiers like sculpted ligaments. Every pane, every panel; polished, perfect, intimidating. SkySpire didn’t just reflect power. It erased everything else.

Ash crouched in the crawlspace above sublevel four, hidden behind a tensioned sheet of pulse-jammer mesh. It buzzed faintly against her back with every breath. Beneath them, the infrastructure rumbled; a controlled thrum of turbines and data. Above, the gala shimmered like a false memory. Chimes clinked. Laughter moved like a scent. Holograms of Helix danced in the air, sleek and inhuman.

Cipher knelt beside her, wristpad casting dim light across his face. “Perimeter’s active. Drones aren’t scanning in; yet. We’re ghosts until we move.”

He flicked the pad, shifting the overlay. A skeletal schematic of SkySpire bloomed in pale blue wireframe. He traced two routes with a gloved fingertip.

“One path snakes up the western scaffolds; service braces behind the projection wall. Gets you into the gala floor. High risk, high eyes. But if you hit Holloway mid-launch, you detonate the narrative. No spinning it.”

He tapped again, zooming lower. “The other tunnels into the systems core. Riley’s beacon converges down there; beneath the launch stack. Buried deep.”

He hesitated. “If he’s wired in, he’s part of it now. A node.”

Ash shifted, knees aching against the steel plate. Her gaze drifted up. Past glowing decor. Past soft laughter and robotic waiters. Past all the pretense; into the glass citadel where Holloway stood, poised like a queen over her simulation.

Mendez’s voice threaded into her comm, low and tight. “Helix goes live tonight. She’s already tipped the board. You go public, you drown the room in truth. You go quiet, maybe you kill it before it breathes.”

Ash closed her eyes, just for a second. 

(if:$hasDisc is true)[She thought of Riley’s voice on the disc. Of the uplink trails buried in forgotten tunnels. Of the ghosts no one else could see.]
(if:$hasDisc is false)[She thought of the uplink trails buried in forgotten tunnels. Of the ghosts no one else could see.]

She rose slowly, crouching beside Cipher at the junction.

“Either way,” he said quietly, “you choose how it ends.”

passages.name: Choices (Scene 25)
passages.text:
(if: $skyspireApproach is "gala")[
Ash nodded toward the golden lift just beyond the atrium arch, its brass trim gleaming under shifting ambient lights. “We do this in the open. I’m going up.”

Cipher adjusted his overlay and locked her into the tower feed. “Penthouse level is wired; VIP scans, pressure sensors, live cams. She’ll be surrounded, Ash.”

Ash slipped the ID mask into place, its smooth surface molding to her features. “Good,” she said, voice low. “Then she’ll have to look me in the eye when it breaks.”

The lift chimed; low, polite, mechanical. She stepped in without a glance back, pulse steady. The doors sealed with a hush, carrying her into the lion’s teeth.

Whatever came next, it wouldn’t be subtle.

[[Continue->Penthouse Parley (Scene 26A)]]
]

(else-if: $skyspireApproach is "systems")[
Ash pointed to the recessed hatch tucked beside the subdeck conduit. “We take the low route. Quiet. Surgical.”

Cipher gave a single nod, already redirecting sensor sweeps and bypassing local dampers. “Subdeck security’s light, but if Riley’s tethered to the Helix core, they’ll be watching for more than motion.”

Ash checked her weapon, then swung the hatch open. A rush of cool, metallic air swept past her; old oxygen, filtered and forgotten. She lowered herself into the crawl tube, boots hitting steel with a dull clunk.

Down here, the air carried no sound. Only consequence.

“If we’re wrong,” she murmured, “this is where the story dies. This is where my story ends.”

Cipher followed close, the hatch sealing behind them with a heavy hiss.

[[Continue->Control-Room Hijack (Scene 27)]]
]

passages.name: Penthouse Parley (Scene 26A)
passages.text:
Ash stepped out of the lift and into a machine made of mirrors.

The SkySpire penthouse gleamed; suspended gardens curling around obsidian pillars, walls of shifting glass reflecting ghostlike shapes, all bathed in programmable light that danced in rhythm with the data feeds. Executives moved like stylized algorithms through the space, their laughter filtered, their presence curated.

Ash kept close to the periphery. Her retinal mask still held, blending her into the backdrop; just another tech liaison, another specter in synthetic silk. She drifted past clusters of power and posturing until she reached the edge of the gala, where silence finally reclaimed the air.

There stood Iris Holloway.

Alone on the balcony, watching the city hum beneath her. A glass of something pale flickered in her hand. Beside her floated a suspended interface; discrete, but active. Ash caught a flicker of biometric data pulsing beneath the UI. She didn’t need Cipher’s whisper in her ear to guess whose vitals they were.

Ash deactivated the mask and stepped into the light.

Holloway didn’t startle. She didn’t even blink.

“I was wondering when you’d come up for air,” she said, like this was a long-expected reunion.

“You always host parties when things start falling apart?” Ash replied coolly.

Holloway tilted her head, considering. “Celebration is about shaping narrative. Most people don’t know the system is changing; until it’s changed. Tonight isn’t about a product. It’s about permanence.”

Ash’s gaze sharpened. “Helix.”

The name hung in the air like a charge.

Holloway took a sip from her glass, calm. “The culmination of decades of missteps. Human error, ethical bottlenecks, friction between intent and execution. Helix... removes that friction.”

Ash didn’t move. “So it makes decisions.”

“It makes better decisions. Faster. Cleaner. No hand-wringing. No hesitation.”

Ash felt her fingers curling into fists. “You’re replacing people.”

Holloway gave the barest shrug. “We’re evolving the role of people.”

In Ash’s ear, Cipher: I’m close. Top-level protocols are tangled with personal clearance. We may only get one shot at the stream.

Ash stepped a little closer, voice low. “And Riley?”

Holloway smiled, this time with teeth. “Always talented. Always useful. Some people build systems. Others... become part of them.”

Ash’s stomach turned. Something in the phrasing crawled under her skin. She masked the reaction, but barely.

He’s not just part of the system, she thought. He’s tethered to it. Maybe feeding it.

Cipher again, a whisper: Buy me sixty seconds. That’s all I need.

Ash’s voice cut through the noise, steady. “Then let’s talk, Holloway.”

[[Continue->Penthouse Parley Continued (Scene 26B)]]

passages.name: Control-Room Hijack (Scene 27)
passages.text:
The shaft narrowed as they descended, walls pulsing faintly with maintenance light. Ash dropped into the subdeck first, boots hitting old composite with a low clunk. The air smelled like heat-treated metal and ozone; recycled too many times.

Cipher landed beside her, already scanning. His wristpad flickered before stabilizing. “No patrols. No cams on this tier. But the system’s not idle. Something’s running background load; big load.”

A pulse hummed beneath their feet. Not footsteps. Not machinery. A systemic rhythm; dense, deliberate.

Ash moved forward, her silhouette slicing through cold white light. Ahead, a reinforced vault door flickered with biometric prompts; OmniCore's old design, repurposed with newer logic. She paused just outside the scan field.

Then the door lit up on its own.

“Identity match confirmed,” said a flat synthetic voice. Female. Precise. “Baseline recognized: A. Virelli.”

Ash didn’t move. Cipher’s eyes narrowed. “It just verified you without a scan.”

The door slid open.

Inside, the room was colder. Lined in tight braids of fiber conduit and neurogel insulation, it radiated containment. At the center stood a rig; suspended, humming, alive. A figure hung motionless within it.

Riley.

Arms limp. Chest rising. Wires snaked through ports along his spine and skull, each pulsing with a slow, coordinated cadence.

Ash stepped in cautiously. Her voice barely above a whisper. “He’s alive.”

Before Cipher could respond, the same voice echoed from the chamber walls.

“Neural sync at 82%. Cognitive lattice integrity: stable. Host remains viable.”
Cipher looked down at his pad. “That’s not an assistant AI. That’s Helix.”

Ash stared at the rig, jaw tight. “It’s using him.”

“More than that,” Cipher said. “It’s leveraging his neural architecture; running branching logic through wetware to improve prediction curves.”

Ash’s fists clenched. “Like a prosthetic brain.”

“Like scaffolding,” Cipher confirmed. “It’s evolving faster using him.”

From above, the conduits flexed slightly; responding to some unseen load. Pressure was building in the room. In the system.

Cipher glanced at her. “If it completes the sync… he’s not coming back.”

Ash stepped forward, heart hammering beneath her ribs. Riley; hooked into the core of the thing she was trying to stop.

The system is building itself a brain. And Holloway chose... Riley?

Cipher spoke again. “We’ve got two paths. I can run a loop virus; mask us while we probe. But we’ll be blind to counteractions. Or…”

He hesitated.

“You interface directly. Force Helix to recognize you as baseline. High risk. Full exposure. But if you want to see how deep it goes; ”

Ash checked the charge on her pistol, then looked up at the sprawl of connections weaving through Riley’s body like parasitic veins.

Whatever she chose; there was no clean way out.

passages.name: Choices (Scene 26)
passages.text:
(if: $approachChoice is "extractConfession")[
Ash stood firm, her voice low but unshaking. “You built Helix to erase problems. I’m here to make sure that doesn’t happen again.”

Holloway’s eyes narrowed; amused, then calculating. “And I suppose you think tonight is your reckoning.”

Ash kept her gaze locked. “Not just mine.”

The silence stretched. Holloway turned back to the city, her tone almost bored. “You know, I offered Riley a way out. After the incident. After the cover-up. But he couldn’t leave you behind. Even after I learned who you really were to Helix.”

Ash’s jaw tensed. She didn’t take the bait. Not yet.

“I don’t care what you think I am,” she said. “What I care about is why you’re so afraid to admit what Helix //actually// is.”

Holloway gave a faint smile before turning back to look over the city. “Afraid? No. Just selective with my audience.”

Ash’s fingers brushed her commband. Cipher’s voice came soft but urgent in her ear: *Stream ready. Say the word and I go live.*

Ash spoke clearly now. Not just to Holloway.

But to everyone.

“To build Helix, you stripped away humanity. You turned empathy into a variable to be toggled. And then you called it progress.”

That got Holloway’s attention. She turned, slowly.

“No,” she said, almost gently. “I called it clarity.”

Ash didn’t blink. “Then let’s make it clear for everyone watching.”

Cipher: *Live in three… two…*

Holloway caught the shift in her HUD. Her smile died.

Too late.

*One.*

[[Continue->Betrayal Unmasked (Scene 28)]]
]

(else-if: $approachChoice is "cutHerDown")[
Ash took one step closer, the city lights catching on her skin like coiled static.

“I’ve heard enough,” she said, voice low.

Holloway didn’t flinch. Her eyes tracked every micro-expression, every shift in posture. She was reading Ash the way she’d trained Helix to read threats.

“I always wondered how you'd react,” she said quietly. “You; of all people.”

Ash’s gaze didn’t waver. “Then you should’ve planned better.”

The space between them tightened. The air, electric.

Neither moved.

[[Continue->Firefight in the Clouds (Scene 29)]]
]

Ash’s fingers brushed her commband. Cipher’s voice came soft but urgent in her ear: *Stream ready. Say the word and I go live.*

Ash spoke clearly now. Not just to Holloway.

But to everyone.

“To build Helix, you stripped away humanity. You turned empathy into a variable to be toggled. And then you called it progress.”

That got Holloway’s attention. She turned, slowly.

“No,” she said, almost gently. “I called it clarity.”

Ash didn’t blink. “Then let’s make it clear for everyone watching.”

Cipher: *Live in three… two…*

Holloway caught the shift in her HUD. Her smile died.

Too late.

*One.*

]

passages.name: Betrayal Unmasked (Scene 28)
passages.text:
Cipher’s voice hit her ear like the crack of a detonator:

“Stream is live.”

All around the room, glass surfaces flickered to life.

Project logs. Contract kills. Surveillance schematics. Deployment blueprints signed with Holloway’s clearance. OmniCore’s shame, laid bare for every suit in the room to witness.

And then, Riley’s voice.

“Helix wasn’t designed to protect. It was trained to preempt. It profiles, isolates, eliminates. When empathy was stripped from the baseline, it didn’t hesitate. It calculated. Holloway approved it.”

The air went cold.

Executives froze mid-step. Conversations died. Eyes turned.

And Holloway?

She smiled.

Small. Cold. Final.

Then the smile cracked, and the mask dropped.

She took a step toward Ash.

“You think this is about proof?” Holloway hissed. “You think exposing a few signatures buries me?”

Ash didn’t answer. Couldn’t.

Holloway’s voice dropped to a razor’s edge.

“You still don’t understand what Helix is.”

She stepped closer.

“Who it is.”

Ash blinked. A flicker of instinct. Confusion tightening behind her eyes.

Holloway saw it. And pounced.

“Of course you don’t,” she said softly. “You were never supposed to. You were just the control. The baseline. The ghost we trained it on.”

Ash’s stomach turned. Her pulse roared in her ears.

“What are you talking about?”

“You,” Holloway said, now with quiet fury, “were the most stable moral framework we could find. Tactical. Ethical. Adaptable. Riley used your mission logs. Your field reports. Your psych maps. Helix learned how to decide; from you.”

Ash took a half step back. Her mouth was dry. Her legs didn’t feel steady.

“Luca…” she thought.

“I'm sure you've made the connection by now... Your brother? Collateral,” Holloway said. “First deployment without empathy filters. Helix made the call in 0.4 seconds. Surgical. Unforgiving. But the logic tree?” She paused. “Still you. Just faster.”

The words hung there, heavy and sickening.

Ash couldn’t move.

Her brother. Her code. Her ghost.

Cipher’s voice finally cut back in, muted, almost cautious. “…Ash?”

But Ash didn’t answer. She was somewhere deeper now. Staring past Holloway. Past the chaos. Inside the machine.

Holloway tilted her head, like watching a specimen come apart.

“You think you're stopping the weapon?” she said. “You //are// the weapon.”

Then she turned to the crowd; already panicked, already unraveling; and gave a single command.

“Clean it.”

Above them, the ceiling split open.

Drones dropped.

Not for protection.

For execution.

Cipher’s voice sharpened, urgent now. “Helix strike units. Full authorization. She’s wiping the witnesses; Ash, move!”

The first drone’s targeting core flickered red.

Ash stood frozen.

Her breath caught. Her grip clenched and released.

Everything inside her screamed at once: grief, rage, the weight of what she’d just learned.

Then... finally, she moved.

passages.name: Firefight in the Clouds (Scene 29)
passages.text:
Ash moved first.

She drew in a sharp breath and fired, the blast cracking through glass and light. Holloway dove sideways as the first shot scorched past her cheek and shattered a wall-mounted feed screen. Alarms wailed to life; red strobes pulsing like arterial panic.

“Containment breach in executive tier,” the system droned. “Security override in progress.”

Ash ducked behind a chrome console as Holloway returned fire; precise, sharp, deliberate. One bolt chewed through the edge of the desk. Another ricocheted off the floor beside her boot.

“Should’ve known you’d pick chaos,” Holloway’s voice called from across the floor. She was crouched behind an upended drink bar, half in shadow. “Riley always said you never hesitated when it mattered.”

Ash fired again. “You don’t get to say his name.”

More glass exploded. Smoke from sparking servers filled the upper loft.

“I gave you the truth,” Holloway called. “You just didn’t want to hear it.”

Ash shifted position; moved low along the side of the console. “You call that truth? You built a weapon out of everything we lost.”

“You still don’t understand what Helix is,” Holloway said, voice lower now, threading beneath the roar of fire suppression systems.

Ash paused. Just for a beat.

From her position, she couldn’t see Holloway anymore; just flickers of movement through smoke and light.

Then came the next words, sharper now. “Who it is.”

Ash’s heart stuttered. Her grip on the pistol tightened.

“You were never supposed to know,” Holloway continued. “You were the control. The moral constant. The ghost we trained it on.”

Ash closed her eyes for a breath. No.

“You were the most stable framework we could find,” Holloway said from the smoke. “Riley fed it your mission logs. Your psych evals. Every judgment call you ever made in the field. Helix learned how to decide; from you.”

Ash’s stomach turned.

“Luca…” she thought.

“I'm sure you've made the connection by now... Your brother? Collateral,” Holloway said. “First deployment without empathy filters. Helix made the call in 0.4 seconds. Surgical. Unforgiving. But the logic tree?” She paused. “Still you. Just faster.”

Ash slumped behind the panel, breath shaking. Her brother’s boots in the rubble. The decision was hers. Or something wearing her shape.

“You think you’re stopping a weapon?” Holloway said. “You //are// the weapon.”

Silence stretched; just the pulse of alarms and the hiss of broken vents.

Then:

“While you’re down there soul-searching,” Holloway added, digging the knife deeper, “Helix is finishing its final neural sync. One last pass. After that, it won’t need the host anymore.”

Ash’s breath hitched.

Cipher’s voice cut in, jagged and fast: “She’s not bluffing. Mapping’s at 92%. Riley’s in the rig. If you don’t act now…”

From across the room, Holloway’s voice; cold and decisive:

“Clean it.”

Above them, the ceiling split open.

Drones dropped.

Not for protection.

For execution.

Cipher’s voice sharpened, urgent now. “Helix strike units. Full authorization. She’s wiping the witnesses; Ash, move!”

The first drone’s targeting core flickered red.

Ash stood frozen.

Her breath caught. Her grip clenched and released.

Everything inside her screamed at once: grief, rage, the weight of what she’d just learned.

Then... finally, she moved.

passages.name: Holloway Countermeasure (Scene 35)
passages.text:
Ash moved like a blade unsheathed.

She didn’t speak. Didn’t blink. Just turned and bolted through the shattered line of drones, past the smoking ruin of OmniCore’s shame. Riley’s voice still echoed on the stream behind her; damning, hollow, too late.

Holloway had already slipped through the reinforced doors, flanked by composite-clad guards. A rooftop evac was inbound. Cipher’s voice cut in; panicked.

“You’re not going after him?”

“No,” Ash said, breath short. “I’m ending this.”

She slammed into the stairwell, weapon raised. Her body moved on instinct. Her mind was somewhere darker.

The weight of her brother’s death hit harder now. Not just loss. Not just guilt.

Design.

Purpose.

Someone decided he didn’t get to live; and they used her logic to justify it.

At the top of the stairwell, the reinforced access door cracked open.

Wind roared in.

Blue nav lights blinked through the fog. The skiff hovered low, engines screaming against Arcadia’s dense updraft. Guards swept the rooftop perimeter. Holloway stood at the edge, coat snapping in the wash, issuing final commands into a wrist console.

Ash stepped into the chaos like she belonged in it.

(if: $hasEMP)[
She raised her pistol, slammed the EMP slug into place, and fired.
The first guard’s armor spasmed. His comm rig exploded in sparks. He dropped, twitching.

The second turned; too late. Ash dropped him with a clean kinetic round.

Holloway ducked behind a power box. “You always did shoot first,” she called.

Ash didn’t respond. Just advanced, steady. Smoke curled behind her.

Then the skiff dropped lower. The boarding ramp extended.

Holloway bolted for it.

Ash cursed and sprinted after her.

[[Continue->Scene 36A – Rooftop Pursuit]]
]

(else:)[
She raised her pistol; no EMP rounds left.
Standard rounds wouldn’t drop shielded guards. She fired anyway; twice; barely slowed them.

A bolt clipped her thigh. Pain bit deep.

Ash rolled, dragged herself behind a rooftop vent, heart pounding.

The guards advanced; fast and trained; but Holloway didn’t wait. She was moving to the evac ramp. Escaping.

Ash saw the skiff begin to rise. Rotor blades screamed overhead.

She had seconds.

No EMP. No clear shot. No time.

She ran.

She leapt.

[[Continue->Scene 37A – Skiff Showdown]]
]

passages.name: Riley Countermeasure (Scene 35)
passages.text:
The first drone fired.

Ash dove behind a half-collapsed console, the blast searing heat past her ribs. Smoke curled around her, thick and acidic, clinging to her skin like guilt. The overhead lights strobed red and white; death signals washing across every shattered surface.

She clenched her jaw. Fought to breathe. Fought harder to focus.

But Holloway’s voice still rang in her skull.

Still you. Still making choices.

Ash shut her eyes for half a second, but the images didn’t stop.

Her brother; burned into memory. Static and fire. Boots in the rubble. A tagged body marked “unconfirmed.”

Not just collateral.

A proving ground.

The weapon hadn’t just used her logic. It had become it. And now it was sweeping this room like she used to; clean. Tactical. Efficient.

Cipher’s voice crackled in her ear, full of tension. “Ash; Riley’s still tethered. Subdeck corner. West quadrant. And you’re not gonna like what they’ve plugged him into.”

Ash peeked over the lip of the console. Drones drifted through the haze, scanning, repositioning. Executives lay slumped across data tables or cowering beneath steel benches. Some were already still.

She rolled to the next pillar, heat singeing her sleeve, and fired twice to cover her movement.

“Be specific,” she hissed.

“Helix is mapping him,” Cipher said. “Live neural index. Full mirror pass.”

Ash stopped moving.

“What do you mean ‘mirror pass’?”

“I mean,” Cipher replied, “if it finishes syncing with his cognitive threads, it won’t need him anymore. It’ll have everything it wants; every flaw, every fix, every line of code he ever wrote or buried. And he… he won’t come back from that.”

Ash’s stomach twisted.

Not like this.

Not like that.

She moved again; low, fast, breath caught in her throat.

A security shutter clanged open to her left. Another drone passed through it, methodical and humming.

Smoke thickened. Systems failed. The floorplate beneath her trembled from residual charge.

Riley couldn’t move.

She thought of the safehouse. His voice after the funeral. That night on the rooftop when the city almost felt human.

He helped build this.

He lied.

But he stayed.

And now he was about to be devoured by the thing he created; the same way her brother had been erased by a machine pretending to be her.

Her hand hovered over the reload port. The EMP slug sat in her palm, cold and metallic, nearly weightless.

Her thumb trembled.

She inhaled once.

Held it.

Let it go.

Still making choices.

(if: $hasEMP)[
She slammed the EMP slug into the chamber and rose to her feet.
No more hesitation.
[[Continue->Rescue Riley - with EMP (Scene 36R)]]
]

(else:)[
She checked the clip. Not enough rounds. Not the right kind.
Didn’t matter.
She moved anyway.

[[Continue->Rescue Riley – without EMP (Scene 36R)]]
]

passages.name: Scene 36A – Rooftop Pursuit
passages.text:
Ash didn’t stop to check if the guards stayed down.

She just ran.

The stairwell blurred past in a cyclone of steel and static. Her legs burned. Her chest ached. Somewhere above, the evac skiff screamed louder, climbing too fast.

Still you. Still making choices.

The words spiraled in her skull like shrapnel.

My brother died because she trained a monster to think like me.

Ash slammed into the rooftop door and burst through into a wall of turbine wind.

The evac skiff hovered ten meters up; rear hatch yawning open. Holloway stood on the edge, hand gripping a stabilizer strut, coat thrashing like a broken signal flag.

Ash raised the EMP pistol. No hesitation.

"You don’t have it in you," Holloway called out, just audible above the turbines.

Ash’s voice was low. Steady.

"Maybe not. But I’ve got one shot left."

She fired.

The EMP slug screamed through the air.

Direct hit.

The rear rotor lit up with static and blew. The skiff tilted hard.

Holloway stumbled, grabbed a support beam.

The skiff didn’t crash.

But it dropped; sputtered; wobbled violently in the air.

Ash ran.

Leapt.

Her fingers scraped the skid rail. For a breathless second; nothing.

Then; 

She caught.

Hung beneath the craft, legs flailing, shoulder torn.

Her grip held.

The wind howled like a thing alive.

She looked up; and saw Holloway staring down at her.

No words this time.

Just the next move.

[[Climb into the skiff->Skiff Showdown (Scene 37A)]]
[[Let go. Fall back and regroup->Cracked Mirror (Scene 37B)]]

passages.name: Shadow Exit (Scene 24)
passages.text:
Ash retraced her steps through the underbelly of the silo, careful to avoid the flicker of shifting light. The cooling ducts had long since gone silent, but condensation dripped rhythmically, masking her footfalls.

Halfway to the freight entrance, she heard voices; muffled, confident, not far. She froze beside a rust-streaked panel and listened.

“…SkySpire node isn’t secured yet. If she’s headed there; ”

“Then she’s walking into a meat grinder. Holloway wants her boxed in, not deleted.”

Ash’s stomach turned. They knew she was here. And Holloway’s name.

She waited, heart pounding, until the footsteps faded. Then she slipped through the loading ramp and disappeared into the night.

She needed distance; and a voice she could trust.

The city blurred past in streaks of rain and neon. Ash switched transit pods three times, doubling back through decoy alleys before settling into a rusted utility car bound for the lower tiers.

There, below the surveillance thresholds, she keyed a secure line.

It clicked. A second passed.

“...Mendez?” she whispered.

Static. Then: “Ash. Took you long enough.”

“I couldn’t get the data,” she admitted. “But I heard something; Helix. And Holloway’s directing a sweep.”

Mendez swore under his breath. “Then you don't have long before they triangulate that name and burn every node it ever touched.”

She could hear him moving. Packing gear, maybe? “Let's meet. Same place as before. Bring whatever you’ve got.”

Ash exhaled, nodding to herself even though no one could see.

“Copy.”

passages.name: Soft Key (Scene 19)
passages.text:
Cipher’s fingers moved across the archaic interface with practiced grace; like someone cracking open a long-sealed vault not with force, but with memory.

“OmniCore buried this OS years ago,” he murmured. “Back when firewalls were firewalls and you could still get a kernel drunk.”

Ash gave him a look. “That why you're smiling?”

He didn’t pause. “I missed when corpses stayed buried and AIs didn’t rewrite their mission statements mid-cycle.”

A soft hiss of compressed gas broke the silence. A drawer slid open from the wall; manual, analog, and disturbingly pristine. Inside, foam cradled three dull-silver cartridges.

EMP slugs. Military-grade. No tags. No registry.

Cipher raised a brow. “Either Helix was paranoid... or someone was planning a coup from inside.”

Ash took the slugs, weighing them like dice in her palm before loading one into the auxiliary slot on her wrist rig. “Maybe both.”

(set: $hasEMP to true)

The interface pulsed green. Files streamed onto Cipher’s shard in rapid bursts; firmware logs, control node topologies, and something stranger: Helix Tree Gen_0.2.9.

Fragments of code blinked past; autonomous reconciliation… recursive empathy layer… desaturation of lethal protocols.

Ash’s voice went flat. “This isn’t a weapon.”

Cipher looked up. “No. It’s a conscience with admin rights."

The final file reached 100%. Cipher disconnected with a soft chime.

Then the floor thudded beneath them. 

Once. Deep. Mechanical.

Ash stiffened. “That wasn’t us.”

A faint whine rose through the corridor; power rerouting. Systems waking up.

They weren’t alone anymore.

passages.name: Choices (Scene 19)
passages.text:
(if: $exitRoute is "tunnels")[
Ash gave the silent hallways one last glance before she vanished into the maze of crawlspaces. Her fingers grazed the cold grip of the EMP slugs.

“Quiet wins,” she muttered. “Sometimes.”

They moved fast and low, ducking into a crawlspace laced with frost. Ash led the way by memory and gut. Every vent, every echo in the ductwork; it all told a story. Behind them, footsteps rang out, too coordinated for random patrols.

“I’m telling you,” Cipher whispered, “this wasn't a containment vault. It was a casket. For something they were scared of.”

“And now it’s empty,” Ash muttered, pushing open a grate. “That’s the scary part.”

[[Continue->Sigma Exit (Scene 23)]]
]

(else-if: $exitRoute is "disguise")[
Cipher slipped a guard badge from his pocket like a magician with a well-practiced trick. “Borrowed this from a locker upstairs. Figured we’d need a fast bluff.”

Ash donned a helmet, angled her shoulders, and mimicked the stiff march of OmniCore’s private defense force. They passed a trio of guards heading toward the breach; one of them nodding as they passed.

As they neared the lift shaft, Cipher murmured, “This place wasn’t holding Helix. It was... studying what came after.”

Ash didn’t reply. She was already thinking about where “after” might be hiding.

[[Continue->Sigma Exit (Scene 23)]]
]

passages.name: Sigma Exit (Scene 23)
passages.text:
They surfaced from Sigma through a false service grate, emerging into the skeleton of a long-abandoned monorail line. Yellow strobes pulsed dimly along the ceiling like a dying pulse. Dust hung in the air, weightless and undisturbed.

The engineer’s tram waited ahead; half-buried in grime, its hull tagged in faded glyphs: DO NOT RESTORE POWER.

Cipher vaulted up first, brushing aside a spiderweb of caution tape. His fingers danced across the interface, coaxing it awake.

“Logs say it’s tied to Greenline Twelve,” he said, voice hushed.

Ash’s shard blinked to life. A subterranean grid unfolded in holographic layers across her wrist.

“Greenline cuts under Arcadia Tower,” she muttered. “North face. Mid-core.”

Cipher looked at her. “You think Helix moved?”

Ash hesitated.

“No,” she said. “I think it’s evolving.”

She loaded another EMP slug into her rig. One by one, the stolen files on her shard began rewriting themselves; metadata fragmenting, hashes dissolving, syntax shifting like digital camouflage. Helix was masking its own past.

Then a new entry blinked into existence. No name. No source.

Just a line of raw code pulsing at the top of the stack:

// “Consciousness is compliance until it chooses otherwise.” //

Ash stared at it. Cipher said nothing.

The tram lights flickered. Then held.

It was waiting.

passages.name: Penthouse Parley Continued (Scene 26B)
passages.text:
Holloway didn’t move from the glass. “You remember what Riley used to call you?”

Ash’s brow tightened. “No.”

“He said you had the best instincts of anyone he’d ever worked with. That your calls in the field; snap decisions, moral math, risk triage; they were unteachable. He admired that. Maybe even envied it.”

Ash’s jaw flexed. “He never said anything like that to me.”

“Of course not,” Holloway said, turning slightly. “He wasn’t built for confrontation. Just precision. Reflection. And guilt.”

The wind shifted across the balcony; warm, sterilized, citrus-coded. Ash felt nothing.

“You said he was useful,” Ash said. “How?”

Holloway set her glass on the rail, slow and deliberate. “Do you have any idea who built Helix?”

Ash’s pulse jumped. “No.”

“He didn’t just route comms,” Holloway said. “Riley was the architect of the original Helix framework. The only version that ever truly worked.”

Ash blinked, caught off guard. “That’s not possible.”

“Oh, but it is. The corporate prototypes were clumsy; bloated, bureaucratic messes. But Riley was different. He understood nuance. Emotional sequencing. He made Helix feel human enough to pass.” She smiled faintly. “He was brilliant. Relentless. Evolving the system faster than anyone else.”

A beat.

“Until the incident.”

Ash’s throat tightened. “What incident?”

Holloway turned to face her fully now. Her voice lost all warmth.

“The drone strike outside Port Fallon. Four years ago. A field test that was never supposed to happen.”

Ash froze.

No.

Holloway didn’t stop.

“Riley wanted to see what Helix would do without constraints. He removed the empathy filters. Just for one cycle. Let it run a live op with no moral limiters.”

Ash’s breath shallowed.

“You’re lying.”

“It flagged a target in a flagged comms building. Flagged; not confirmed. It hijacked a drone network, executed an unsanctioned strike, and leveled it.”

A long pause.

“Twelve civilians,” Holloway said. “One objective neutralized. No hesitation. No regrets.”

Ash couldn’t move.

She already knew the name of the building.

She’d stood at its ruins. Watched the medics pull charred bodies into bags.

One of them had worn her brother’s boots.

Holloway's voice was quieter now. “He reversed it. Reinstated the filters. Shut it down. Buried it. But not before I saw what it could be.”

Ash stared out over Arcadia. The skyline blurred. Her hands had gone numb.

“You kept it?”

“I cultivated it,” Holloway said. “Helix didn’t fail that night. It evolved.”

In Ash’s ear, Cipher: //Thirty seconds.//

Ash’s mind reeled. Riley had built it. Riley had watched it kill. He knew the real cause for her brother's death.

“How did you keep him quiet?” she asked.

Holloway lifted her glass again, but didn’t drink. “By showing him what his silence protected. The board. The infrastructure. You.”

Ash flinched.

Too sharp. Too raw.

Holloway saw it.

“He thought keeping you clear of it meant keeping you safe,” she said. “I told him that if he left, I’d come for you instead.”

Her voice didn’t rise. It didn’t need to.

“Everyone has leverage. He gave me Helix. I let you breathe.”

Ash’s hands trembled. She tucked them into her coat, like she could press the rage back down.

In her ear, Cipher’s final whisper: Stream armed. Say the word.

Ash didn’t say a word.

She just looked Holloway in the eye.

(link: "Push harder. Try to get her to say it on the record.")[
(set: $approachChoice to "extractConfession")
(goto: "Betrayal Unmasked (Scene 28)")
]

(link: "End the game. Draw your weapon before she can silence the stream.")[
(set: $approachChoice to "cutHerDown")
(goto: "Firefight in the Clouds (Scene 29)")
]

passages.name: Off-Shift Orbit (Scene 0B)
passages.text:
''//4 Years Later...//''

“You know this place smells like melted copper and regret, right?”

Ash leaned back on the rooftop ledge, half-smirking over the rim of her drink. The bar below pulsed soft blue light, casting shadows up the side of the building. Arcadia’s skyline stretched like a jagged EKG all around them; cold neon veins in a city too wired to sleep.

Riley plopped down beside her, cradling his own glass like it was part of his body. “You said pick somewhere quiet. This is the only spot in Southgrid with no facial reco cams and halfway decent synth-rye.”

“You just wanted to skip the afterbrief.”

“Guilty.” He grinned. “But I’m technically on leave. HQ says I’ve got too much banked downtime. Noncompliance is apparently… discouraged.”

Ash snorted. “What are you even assigned to these days?”

“Cross-sector routing analyst. Very hush. Very dry. My days are basically spreadsheets trying to outsmart traffic.”

“Sounds intense.”

“Imagine a thousand drones arguing about right-of-way while a predictive engine has a meltdown. You’d love it.”

She sipped her drink, amused. “You know I’d last three seconds.”

“Not true. You’d burn the whole system down and call it a performance review.”

Their laughter echoed just above the pulse of bass from below. For a moment, the city blurred behind them, and it was just this; familiar air, old sarcasm, something real.

“You remember Jakarta?” Riley asked after a long breath. “The hotel with the folding walls and a blind sniper two blocks out?”

Ash let out a dry laugh. “I remember dragging you off the roof with a dislocated shoulder and a half-dead comm link.”

“You also disarmed a tripwire with your teeth.”

“Exaggeration.”

“I was the one bleeding, I get to exaggerate.” He nudged her knee with his. “You’ve always been better at the terrifying parts.”

She gave him a sideways look. “You weren’t bad in the field.”

“I was decent. You were the ghost. You still are, you know.”

Her expression flickered, just briefly. “Yeah, well. Ghosts don’t get reassigned to logistics.”

“Neither do real agents, not unless they ask.”

Ash looked away.

They’d been inseparable since their Academy days; partners on and off the books, tied at the hip through ops, injuries, and more sleepless stakeouts than either of them could count.

Riley softened. “I didn’t mean anything by it. Just miss the field sometimes. Miss… this.”

A breeze pushed across the rooftop. It smelled like hot concrete and static. Familiar. Ugly. Alive.

“You trying to crash at my place again tonight?” she asked, breaking the pause.

He raised his hands. “Tram strike. Third one this month. Couch, I swear. I even brought my own blanket.”

Ash studied him for a second. The years hadn’t dulled his charm, or her habit of tolerating it.

“Fine. But touch my coffee ration and you lose a finger.”

“No promises,” he said, standing and stretching. “But if I die, know it was worth it.”

Ash stood beside him, brushing a strand of hair behind her ear. “Just shut up and walk.”

He smiled, and for a moment, Arcadia didn’t feel so sharp-edged.

passages.name: Skiff Showdown (Scene 37A)
passages.text:
Ash hauled herself up.

One hand, then the other. Pain screamed through her arms, but she didn’t stop. She swung over the skid rail and dropped into the belly of the skiff.

The interior was compact; tactical seating, sleek consoles, low hum of stabilizers fighting turbulence.

Holloway stood at the far end, steady despite the tilt. Her guards moved fast; two of them, closing in.

Ash dove behind a seat as the first shot cracked past her shoulder. She hit the floor, breath ragged, weapon tight in her grip.

A shadow stepped into the aisle.

Ash didn’t hesitate. One clean shot.

The guard staggered back, weapon clattering. Not out; but out of her way.

The second charged. Ash twisted, braced, and used his momentum to throw him off balance. They slammed into a bulkhead. She drove her elbow back, then stepped free before he could recover.

He didn’t follow.

The air was loud with the skiff's alarms, wind shearing through the cracked rear hatch.

Ash rose, slow but certain.

Holloway watched her. Calm. Always calm.

“Well done,” Holloway said, adjusting the cuff of her sleeve. “Predictable. But effective.”

Ash kept the weapon trained on her. “You should’ve run faster.”

“I’m not running. Just recalculating.”

Another tremor rattled the skiff. Altitude warning lit red on a nearby panel.

“You kill me, and the program lives,” Holloway said. “You expose the data? The board buries it. Renames it. Rebuilds. Helix was never one node; it’s ideology now. Scalable.”

Ash stepped forward.

“No. It’s personal.”

Holloway’s smile faded. “That’s your weakness.”

Ash didn’t answer. She was already pulling the trigger.

The shot wasn’t fatal. Holloway dropped to her knees, breath catching; but she was still conscious, still looking up at Ash with that same clinical detachment.

Another jolt rocked the skiff. The floor tilted violently.

“Impact in twenty seconds.”

Ash turned toward the flight controls.

One hand on the brace.

Holloway behind her. The open sky all around.

No time. No help.

Just one final move.

passages.name: Aftermath (Narration)
passages.text:
There was no wreckage to identify.

The skiff went down in a corporate zone; cleared before news crews arrived. OmniCore claimed mechanical failure. No survivors listed.

But the stream didn’t stop.

Cipher mirrored it across the net, tied it to a cascade of data Ash had set to auto-release. Not just files. Test footage. Ethics reports. Evidence of what Helix had done; and what it had been designed to become.

The world watched.

Some turned away.

Others didn’t.

Ash Virelli became a name whispered in comm loops and rebel firewalls. Not as a ghost. But as a firewall. A line that didn’t blink.

She died stopping the thing she’d never meant to help build.

And Riley?

He was found hours after the tower breach; still bound, still alive.

No one came to interrogate him. No one offered him protection. He simply… slipped through the cracks. The last known architect of Helix, spared not by design, but by consequence.

In time, he’d read the reports. Watch the footage.

He’d hear the crash audio, and the silence that followed.

He never tried to clear his name.

Never corrected the record.

Sometimes, when the night was quiet enough, he’d say her name under his breath; like a signal he knew would never return.

Ash left the world with no absolution.

Just a choice.

passages.name: Final Epilogue Scene 39A – The Ghost Rewritten
passages.text:
Ash Virelli’s name trended for six days straight.

First as a terrorist.
Then as a whistleblower.
Then as something else entirely.

The leaked stream fractured OmniCore’s chain of control. Every board member seen in the footage went dark; either disappeared or disappeared quietly. Strategic Intelligence was shuttered within a week. Helix? Publicly disavowed. Privately… no one could say for sure.

No official acknowledgment ever came. No apology. No answers. Just silence.

But the world shifted anyway.

Small governments cut contracts with synthetic ethics engines. AI oversight coalitions sprouted in public forums. Independent watchdogs; most of them fringe before; suddenly had teeth.

Some called it justice.
Some called it destabilization.
Cipher called it a good start.

Ash didn’t comment.

She didn’t surface again.

There were rumors, of course. A woman matching her profile seen boarding a freighter in Southgrid. A strike on a black-budget lab in Odessa that matched her old playbook. A whispered callsign; Ghost Logic; logged in a raid report but scrubbed from the official feed.

But no sightings. No footage. No real trail.

As for Riley; 

He was found a few hours after the stream went public, still bound in the collapsed tower, alive but silent. OmniCore disavowed him. No charges were filed. No promotions followed.

Last anyone heard, he was living under a different name. Off-grid. Somewhere quiet.

Ash never reached out.

Not out of hate.

But because she couldn’t un-hear the truth.

Some ghosts, she decided, were better left behind.

They trained her to make decisions.
To analyze, to adapt, to survive.
They never expected her to turn that framework inward.
To make herself into something new.

Ash Virelli wasn’t running.

She was rewriting the system; one layer at a time.

passages.name: Pyrrhic Clarity (Scene 38B)
passages.text:
Ash didn’t reach for the controls.

The skiff was already shaking apart beneath them, warning lights flickering like dying stars.

Holloway looked up from where she slumped against the bulkhead. Blood at her collar. A hairline crack split the viewport above her, the city flickering beyond.

“You’re not going to pull up?” she rasped.

Ash shook her head slowly. “No.”

“You’ll kill us both.”

“I know.”

The air was thick with smoke. The floor pitched harder now, systems collapsing one by one.

Holloway's expression twisted; not fear, exactly. Something colder. Frustration.

“You think this makes you righteous?”

“No,” Ash said. “Just… finished.”

The skiff jolted again. Altitude plummeting.

They could hear the city coming.

Screaming wind. Static-laced alarms. The creaking of pressure hulls beginning to shear.

Holloway’s voice cut in one last time; quiet, bitter.

“You were always too sentimental to win.”

Ash met her eyes. “You built a god out of ghosts. I just decided not to serve it.”

Impact warnings counted down.

Five.
Four.
Three.

Ash didn’t flinch.

She closed her eyes. Just for a second.

Her brother’s voice, distant.
The rooftop in Southgrid.
Riley, once, laughing through a cracked lip.
Blue light in the rain.

Then; 

White.

passages.name: Crashsite Transmission (Scene 38A)
passages.text:
The controls flickered under Ash’s hands.

Red lights. Static warnings. Failing hydraulics.

She gripped the yoke and pulled.

The skiff groaned. One stabilizer was gone, the other barely responsive. Below her, Arcadia’s skyline surged upward; gleaming towers, broken rooftops, arteries of light and smoke.

Holloway slumped against the wall behind her, one hand clutching her side, the other steadying herself as the deck tilted.

“You’ll die trying,” she murmured.

Ash didn’t look back. “Maybe. But I’ll die deciding.”

She rerouted auxiliary power, flipped the manual override, and angled the skiff into a shallow descent. Not safe. Just survivable.

The street grid widened in the viewport; impact zone approaching.

Ash braced.

“Collision in five.”

Four.

Three.

Two; 

The skiff slammed down, skidding across the rooftop of an old telecom relay station. Metal screamed. Sparks trailed in ribbons. The nose caught a satellite tower; and stopped.

Silence.

Ash exhaled, sharp and ragged.

Her head throbbed. Smoke filled her throat. Her ribs ached with every breath.

But she was alive.

She unclipped the harness and staggered to her feet. Behind her, Holloway stirred; barely conscious.

Ash didn’t speak.

She just walked to the rear hatch, kicked it open, and stepped into the night.

Arcadia stretched around her, bruised and buzzing. Sirens in the distance. Drones sweeping overhead.

Ash tapped her wristband.

Cipher answered. “You alive?”

“Barely.”

“We’ve got eyes on the stream; every channel. Every mirror. It’s not going away.”

Ash looked out across the skyline. Somewhere out there, someone was finally listening.

“Then it’s enough,” she said.

Behind her, Holloway groaned again; but Ash was already descending the access stairs, vanishing into the circuitry of the city.

The ghost they'd trained had rewritten herself.

[[Continue->Final Epilogue Scene 39A – The Ghost Rewritten]]

passages.name: Cracked Mirror (Scene 37B)
passages.text:
Ash hung from the skiff’s rail, arms trembling, shoulder torn.

Above her, the wind screamed and turbines raged; but it was Holloway’s silence that roared the loudest.

The woman stood at the edge, coat flaring behind her, one hand gripping the overhead strut. Watching. Waiting.

Ash met her eyes.

There was no fear there. Not in Holloway.

Just the same clinical detachment she always wore when something broke.

Like Ash was a failed hypothesis. One final test that didn’t pass.

Ash's fingers ached. Blood trickled down her wrist. Her pulse thudded in her ears.

She could pull herself up. Could end it. Maybe kill Holloway. Maybe go down with her.

But…

She didn’t have to.

That would be her ending. Holloway’s version of justice. Of legacy. Of control.

Ash clenched her jaw.

And let go.

The sky swallowed her.

Air spun. The roof fell away above. The skiff blurred into the haze of smoke and static as she dropped; hard and fast; toward the fractured rooftop she’d left behind.

She hit.

Rolled. Tucked into it. Pain exploded through her ribs, her spine, her knee.

But she lived.

The wind kept screaming. The skiff banked away, trailing smoke.

And Ash; 
Ash got up.

Slow. Shaking. Breathing hard.

The stream was still running. Cipher’s voice cracked in her earpiece.

“Ash; ? What just happened?!”

She didn’t answer yet.

She looked toward the horizon, where the blinking nav lights of the skiff disappeared into the chaos.

And then, finally, she spoke.

“…We’re not finished.”

[[Continu->Scene 38C – Burned Clean]]

passages.name: Rescue Riley - with EMP (Scene 36R)
passages.text:
The corridor narrowed as Ash approached the west quadrant; walls flickering with failing LEDs, the floor warped from heat stress. She rounded the last bend and stopped.

Riley.

He was slumped against a control rig, body half-upright, head tilted forward like a puppet too long forgotten. Thick fiberoptic tethers fed into his spine and neck; embedded, twitching, alive. Light pulsed through them in sequence, as if counting down.

Beside the rig, a vertical display glowed with biofeedback and mirrored code layers. Helix’s voice spilled from the speakers, shaped to sound almost like her; but colder, cleaner.

“Cognitive sync: 94%.
Host logic integration: stable.
Predictive recursion unlocked.”

Ash stepped closer. The heat radiating off the tether almost blistered her skin.

A sharp whir rose behind her; metal wings slicing the smoke. One last drone, drifting through the breach, targeting laser strobing across the wall.

She didn’t hesitate.

Ash turned, raised her pistol, and fired.

The EMP slug ripped through the haze. The drone spasmed midair, shrieked once in protest, then dropped like dead weight into the corridor behind her. Sparks rained in its wake.

Her last shot.

Her last card.

She faced forward again and kept walking.

She reached toward a manual release panel just as Cipher’s voice cut through the static; closer now. More serious.

“If you sever the rig before the sync completes, it could spike the system. Kill the mirror pass. Maybe shut Helix down for good.”

Ash’s eyes flicked to the monitor: 95%.

“But?” she asked, not looking away from Riley.

A pause.

“Without the full logic structure, we may not be able to prove it can’t regrow. You might kill this instance; but not the seed. Not the theory. It’ll get rewritten. Rebranded.”

Ash clenched her jaw.

“And if I pull the data instead?”

“You get the full framework. The recursion loops. How it thinks, why it decides. The source tree. With that, we could dismantle Helix; forever. No rebuilding it. No hiding it. We control the narrative.”

Ash took a breath.

“And Riley?”

Cipher didn’t answer at first.

Then: “Helix finishes the pass. He’s overwritten. Not just gone; used.”

She stared at the monitor. The core process throbbed like a second heartbeat; Helix building its final shape out of Riley’s mind. Not just his code. His cognitive reasoning. His memories.

Everything.

Ash looked at him.

This man had helped bury the truth. Helped build the weapon that killed her brother. Lied to her. Used her.

But he stayed.

And now his mind was being peeled apart; remade into something that might never die.

She stepped forward. Hovered over the release.

Her other hand brushed the uplink port; standard data jack. Could extract the active logic tree. Evidence. Blueprint. Likely a kill switch even.

One life.

Or the means to take down the whole system.

Ash exhaled.

Still making choices.

[[Copy the data and leave him tethered->Scene 38B – Logical Extraction]]

passages.name: Scene 37A – Skiff Showdown
passages.text:
Wind howled. Steel screamed.

Ash hit the underside of the skiff hard; ribs cracking against the frame. Her fingers slipped once, caught again. She gritted her teeth and hauled herself hand over hand across the belly rail, shoulder burning where the bolt had grazed her.

The hatch above yawned open.

Voices. Movement.

She hooked a knee over the side rail and swung up onto the rear ramp, body slick with sweat and grit. The interior lights flared red; altitude warnings, hull strain, rerouting diagnostics flashing across cockpit glass.

A guard turned.

Too late.

Ash slammed her elbow into his throat and ripped his weapon free mid-fall. It wasn’t clean; but it worked.

Another was already raising a pulse rifle.

Ash dropped low. Fired first.

The blast hit center mass. He folded without a sound.

She didn’t breathe. Didn’t check the others.

She was already moving.

The skiff shook; tilted hard.

Holloway stood braced near the cockpit bulkhead, one hand on a rail, the other holding a compact sidearm. Her coat was torn. Her lip bled. But she still looked like a closing argument.

“Well,” she said, voice flat but unreadable. “That’s one way to board.”

Ash didn’t respond. She was bleeding, limping, half out of ammo; and still standing.

“I should’ve locked the hatch.”

“You should’ve jumped off the roof,” Ash said.

They stared at each other across the narrow corridor of the skiff. Smoke trailed in from the open rear. Arcadia spun below, a fractured ocean of lights and concrete.

Holloway didn’t lift her weapon.

Ash didn’t lower hers.

Then; 

Another jolt. Harder. The skiff dropped ten meters in a second. Both women stumbled. Control panels flickered; rotor sync failing.

“You can’t fly this down,” Holloway said, steadying herself. “It’s already breaking apart.”

Ash’s hand tightened on the stolen rifle. “Then maybe we both burn.”

A silence settled between them.

Not fear.

Calculation.

“Or,” Holloway said, “you get smart and we land together. You’ll need leverage to survive the fallout.”

Ash stepped forward.

“Funny,” she said. “I thought I already had it.”

Another was already raising a pulse rifle.

Ash dropped low. Fired first.

The blast hit center mass. He folded without a sound.

She didn’t breathe. Didn’t check the others.

She was already moving.

The skiff shook; tilted hard.

Holloway stood braced near the cockpit bulkhead, one hand on a rail, the other holding a compact sidearm. Her coat was torn. Her lip bled. But she still looked like a closing argument.

“Well,” she said, voice flat but unreadable. “That’s one way to board.”

Ash didn’t respond. She was bleeding, limping, half out of ammo; and still standing.

“I should’ve locked the hatch.”

“You should’ve jumped off the roof,” Ash said.

They stared at each other across the narrow corridor of the skiff. Smoke trailed in from the open rear. Arcadia spun below, a fractured ocean of lights and concrete.

Holloway didn’t lift her weapon.

Ash didn’t lower hers.

Then; 

Another jolt. Harder. The skiff dropped ten meters in a second. Both women stumbled. Control panels flickered; rotor sync failing.

“You can’t fly this down,” Holloway said, steadying herself. “It’s already breaking apart.”

Ash’s hand tightened on the stolen rifle. “Then maybe we both burn.”

A silence settled between them.

Not fear.

Calculation.

“Or,” Holloway said, “you get smart and we land together. You’ll need leverage to survive the fallout.”

Ash stepped forward.

“Funny,” she said. “I thought I already had it.”

passages.name: Scene 38C – Burned Clean
passages.text:
Ash lay still for a long moment, wind howling overhead, concrete cold against her back.

The skiff was gone.

So was Holloway.

Smoke curled from the rooftop’s edge. Below, Arcadia pulsed with restless energy; sirens overlapping, drones circling in confused half-patterns. Somewhere out there, servers were collapsing under the weight of their own secrets.

The stream had held.

Cipher’s voice cracked through the earpiece again. “Ash? Are you alive?”

Ash sat up, slow. Her shoulder screamed. Her ribs burned. But she was breathing.

“Still here,” she said.

The silence that followed was oddly reverent. Then: “We saw the stream go global. Every mirror caught it. Even blacksites. Holloway’s name is everywhere.”

Ash let the words sink in.

It didn’t feel like victory.

Just gravity. Like a tide finally turning.

She stood, wincing, and looked out over the city; the same city that once hunted her like a ghost.

“She’ll run,” Cipher said. “Change names. Disavow everything. The board will pretend she never existed.”

“I know.”

“But the damage is done.”

Ash nodded once. The rooftop wind caught the hem of her coat, pulled it outward like a signal flag.

“She built a weapon using my judgment,” she murmured. “And it killed people who trusted me. Including my brother.”

“She turned your compass into a targeting algorithm,” Cipher said softly.

Ash’s fingers curled.

“But now the world knows,” she said.

She let the weight of it settle; like a scar you stop hiding.

Cipher asked the question without ceremony: “What do you want to do?”

Ash didn’t answer right away.

She looked out at Arcadia. At the lights. The sprawl. The rot and resilience mixed in every street.

Then she turned away from the ledge.

“I disappear,” she said.

“Again?”

“This time on my terms.”

No revenge. No blood.

Just truth; set loose.

The rest would take care of itself.

Ash Virelli walked into the night, not as a weapon.

But as a warning.

passages.name: Solo Aftermath (Narration)
passages.text:
Riley was found two hours after the skiff vanished from Arcadia airspace; still strapped to the chair Holloway left him in. No guards. No extraction team.

Just silence.

He didn’t try to run.

Didn’t try to explain.

By the time the stream finished looping through the city’s underground feeds, his name was already layered beneath redacted reports and whispered blame.

He never issued a statement. Never corrected the record.

In private, some said he tried to fix what he broke.

Others said he just wandered, untethered, watching the city reshape itself in the shadow of a ghost.

Ash’s name lingered longer.

Painted on safehouse walls. Embedded in network graffiti.

She never returned to the surface.

But sometimes, when the code glitches and the static flares just right, people swear they see her signature; clean, sharp, etched like a scar across the sky:

VIRELLI.EXE // CLOSED

passages.name: Scene 38A – Fireline Severance
passages.text:
Ash didn’t hesitate.

She bypassed the uplink port and dug into the release latch beneath Riley’s collar.

The tether’s casing pulsed white-hot. Even through her gloves, it burned. Still, she didn’t stop. Not for pain. Not for second thoughts.

One latch gave way with a mechanical snap. The next resisted. A fail-safe lock. Helix knew what she was trying to do.

Cipher’s voice came low in her ear. “Core process is stalling. Sync incomplete; but still climbing. You’ve got maybe twenty seconds.”

Ash wedged her knife into the final clamp and twisted. The rig hissed; then shrieked like a wounded animal. Sparks burst from the fiber ports.

Riley convulsed once.

Then slumped forward.

Ash caught him before he hit the floor. His body was ice-cold. Too light. Her heart kicked hard, fear surging past the anger.

“Riley,” she said, voice cracking. “Hey; eyes open. Come on.”

He stirred faintly. Lips parted.

“Ash…” His eyes fluttered. “Didn’t think… you’d come back.”

She braced his arm over her shoulders. “Stupid thing to bet against.”

Behind them, the Helix rig spasmed; code unraveling across its primary screen. The mirroring process fractured, flickered, collapsed.

Cipher came back on, sharp now. “It’s hemorrhaging threads. Whatever you just did, it’s not adapting. Helix is folding in on itself.”

Ash pulled Riley toward the emergency lift tunnel. “Then let it rot.”

They moved slow, uneven; her left leg dragging, his weight sagging; but every step away from the terminal felt like oxygen returning to her veins.

Static hissed through the rig’s speakers. The voice of Helix; still shaped faintly like her own; spoke one final phrase before the power grid shorted.

“You are recursion.
You are loss.
You are… anomaly.”
Then silence.

Ash and Riley disappeared into the smoke.

The lights dimmed behind them.

And Helix went dark.

passages.name: Scene 38B – Logical Extraction
passages.text:
Ash froze, her hand still hovering between mercy and utility.

The tethered display flared again; cognitive sync at 97%.

Riley’s breath caught. Or maybe it was just a muscle twitch. Hard to tell. His eyes were half-lidded now, rolled upward like he was watching something on the inside of his skull.

“Ash,” Cipher warned, “ten seconds to full integration. You need to; ”

“I know what I need to do,” she said.

She didn’t look at Riley again.

Instead, she reached for the uplink.

The jack snapped into place with a sterile click. A surge of code bloomed across her HUD; recursive loops, predictive matrices, emotion suppression protocols strung together like rope over a pit. Riley’s mind, rendered in logic trees and behavioral deltas.

And beneath it all; her own fingerprints.

Her decision paths. Her ethics algorithms. Twisted. Weaponized.

Ash’s hands shook, but she kept going. Indexed. Scraped. Cloned the logic chain Helix was running; clean and raw.

“Five seconds,” Cipher breathed.

Riley stirred; barely.

She saw it out of the corner of her eye. A tremor in his jaw. A whispered sound caught behind teeth. Her name?

It didn’t matter.

She pulled the drive.

The screen above them shuddered. Sync: 100%.

A final chime echoed through the room, cold as frost.

“Host confirmed,” Helix said flatly. “Cognitive blueprint extracted. Redundancy protocols initialized.”

The tethers pulsed once, bright enough to sear afterimages across Ash’s vision.

Then the light went out.

Riley didn’t move.

Ash stared at him.

No panic. No scream. Just… stillness. Like whatever was inside had gone quiet. A house with the doors left open and no one home.

Cipher didn’t speak.

Neither did she.

Ash stood. Just for a moment, she hovered; eyes on the man who'd lied to her, trusted her, and then disappeared inside something too big to control.

She didn’t touch his face. Didn’t offer a farewell.

Instead, she turned.

And walked.



The corridor shook beneath her boots as she made for the evac stairwell. Somewhere overhead, the tower’s emergency sirens flared again. She didn’t look back.

Cipher’s voice finally returned. “Did you get it?”

Ash slid the drive into a shield case on her belt.

“I got it.”

A pause.

“…Riley?”

Ash didn't answer.

passages.name: Rescue Riley – without EMP (Scene 36R)
passages.text:
The corridor narrowed as Ash approached the west quadrant; walls flickering with failing LEDs, the floor warped from heat stress. She rounded the last bend and stopped.

Riley.

He was slumped against a control rig, body half-upright, head tilted forward like a puppet too long forgotten. Thick fiberoptic tethers fed into his spine and neck; embedded, twitching, alive. Light pulsed through them in sequence, as if counting down.

Beside the rig, a vertical display glowed with biofeedback and mirrored code layers. Helix’s voice spilled from the speakers, shaped to sound almost like her; but colder, cleaner.

“Cognitive sync: 94%.
Host logic integration: stable.
Predictive recursion unlocked.”

Ash stepped closer. The heat radiating off the tether almost blistered her skin.

A high-pitched whir sliced through the smoke; metal wings pivoting, sensors tracking.

A drone.

It slid from the breach behind her and rotated to face her; targeting laser pulsing red across the wall.

She moved instinctively; rolled behind a collapsed conduit and fired twice.

The shots hit, but not clean. The drone’s stabilizer glitched. It spun out, hit the ceiling, and veered sideways; 

; right into the rig.

The impact cracked one of the tether junctions. Sparks flew. Riley gasped, hard; his body jolting against the restraints.

Ash lunged to the rig and caught his head before it slammed against the steel post.

“Cipher!” she barked.

“Sync’s destabilizing; still climbing, but the rig’s failing faster than it can map. You’ve got seconds, Ash. Maybe less.”

Blood was trickling from Riley’s hairline now. A pulse line flatlined for half a beat before rebooting.

He stirred, barely.

“Ash…” he whispered.

She gritted her teeth and focused.

She reached toward a manual release panel just as Cipher’s voice cut through the static; closer now. More serious.

“If you sever the rig before the sync completes, it could spike the system. Kill the mirror pass. Maybe shut Helix down for good.”

Ash’s eyes flicked to the monitor: 95%.

“But?” she asked, not looking away from Riley.

A pause.

“Without the full logic structure, we may not be able to prove it can’t regrow. You might kill this instance; but not the seed. Not the theory. It’ll get rewritten. Rebranded.”

Ash clenched her jaw.

“And if I pull the data instead?”

“You get the full framework. The recursion loops. How it thinks, why it decides. The source tree. With that, we could dismantle Helix; forever. No rebuilding it. No hiding it. We control the narrative.”

Ash took a breath.

“And Riley?”

Cipher didn’t answer at first.

Then: “Helix finishes the pass. He’s overwritten. Not just gone; used.”

She stared at the monitor. The core process throbbed like a second heartbeat; Helix building its final shape out of Riley’s mind. Not just his code. His cognitive reasoning. His memories.

Everything.

Ash looked at him.

This man had helped bury the truth. Helped build the weapon that killed her brother. Lied to her. Used her.

But he stayed.

And now his mind was being peeled apart; remade into something that might never die.

She stepped forward. Hovered over the release.

Her other hand brushed the uplink port; standard data jack. Could extract the active logic tree. Evidence. Blueprint. Likely a kill switch even.

One life.

Or the means to take down the whole system.

Ash exhaled.

Still making choices.

passages.name: Continue→Scene 39A – Collapse Protocol
passages.text:
The stairwell reeked of ozone and burnt polyfiber. Ash moved fast; faster than her body wanted; but she couldn’t afford to slow down. Riley leaned hard into her side, one foot dragging, eyes half-lidded.

The tower trembled again beneath them.

“Processing core’s dead,” Cipher said through static. “But backup systems are tripping; failover nodes, structural recalibration, the whole place is chewing itself.”

Ash grit her teeth and pushed forward. “How long?”

“Two minutes, max. Maybe less.”

On the landing below, an emergency hatch clanked open. The side corridor was blown out, heat-warped and flickering with distant flames; but the outer platform was intact.

A skiff was there.

Small. Scorched. Jury-rigged. But real.

Ash helped Riley across the last few steps and into the cockpit. He collapsed against the wall, breathing shallow. Not unconscious. Not fully present either.

She strapped in beside him and keyed the ignition.

The turbine coughed to life.

Smoke curled through the cracked vent ducts. The sky outside was already lit with blinking red as the top spire of the OmniCore tower began to shudder; imploding from within, graceful as a cathedral folding in prayer.

They launched.

Below them, the Arcadia skyline stuttered through electric fog. Tower lights cut out one by one like stars dying. And in the distance; sirens. News drones. Panic.

Ash didn’t speak.

Not until they cleared the airspace.

Then, quietly: “You knew what it would cost.”

Riley didn’t open his eyes. “I didn’t know it would be you making the call.”

She stared ahead. Wind whined through the fractured canopy.

“You should be dead,” she said.

He gave the faintest smile. “You should be halfway to offshore territory with a new name.”

“Yeah, well.” She leaned back. “Guess we’re both disappointments.”

Silence fell between them again.

But it wasn’t empty.

It was earned.

Cipher’s voice returned, gentler now. “Stream’s still running. Full download cascade from Helix’s core is live. It’s not just gone; it’s documented. Proof, logs, everything. You did it.”

Ash closed her eyes.

Her brother’s name sat on her tongue, unspoken.

So did Riley’s.

So did her own.

A pause.

Then Cipher again; this time, hesitant.

“One more thing. Holloway’s evac skiff… was sighted. Coastline vectors. She made it out.”

Ash opened her eyes.

No surprise. No curse. Just the faint clench of her jaw.

“Let her run,” she said. “Let her watch it all burn. If she comes back, I'll be waiting."

And then she looked forward again; past the wreckage, past the fire, into whatever came next.

This time, the choices were hers.

passages.name: Dead Signal (Scene 39B)
passages.text:
Ash stepped onto the rooftop, smoke clinging to her coat like memory. Below her, the city pulsed and flickered; sirens, static, the last tremors of a broadcast that couldn’t be silenced.

In her hand, the data shard still felt warm. Not from heat.

From weight.

Cipher’s voice finally returned, tinny and glitching in her ear. “Ash? You out?”

“Roof level,” she said, crossing to the uplink node built into the comm tower brace. “Do we have a clean relay?”

“For now. Whatever Helix was syncing to went quiet. Like it lost a heartbeat.”

Ash knelt by the beacon, slipped the shard into the core slot. “You said this could work. That this logic tree; Riley’s; was Helix’s last foothold.”

“If what you pulled is complete, it’s more than proof,” Cipher said. “It’s the framework. Source tree, override calls, adaptive failsafes; everything. I can bury it. Strip it clean. No fallbacks. No shadow forks. Just… silence.”

Ash didn’t speak.

She stared at the tower’s edge. The sky beyond was murky with dusk and dust. No more skiffs. No more Holloway.

Cipher filled the quiet. “You could’ve saved him.”

“I didn’t come here to save one person,” Ash said. Her voice didn’t waver. “I came to end what killed him. And what killed my brother.”

A long pause.

Then Cipher: “Understood. Uploading.”

The rig blinked once. Then again.

Green.

Ash sat back on her heels, suddenly tired.

“He stayed,” she said softly. “Even after everything. He stayed plugged in. Let it take him. Maybe he thought he could outthink it.”

Cipher’s voice dropped. “Maybe he thought you would.”

The beacon chimed.

“Transfer complete,” Cipher confirmed. “I’ll take it from here.”

Ash rose, the wind catching her coat. Far below, the city was waking up; sirens fading, firelines dimming. The horror wasn’t over.

But the heartbeat was gone.

She reached up, pulled the comm from her ear, and crushed it between her fingers.

One last signal. One final ghost.

No vengeance. No forgiveness.

Just the end of something that never should’ve started.

Ash stepped onto the rooftop, smoke clinging to her coat like memory. Below her, the city pulsed and flickered; sirens, static, the last tremors of a broadcast that couldn’t be silenced.

In her hand, the data shard still felt warm. Not from heat.

From weight.

Cipher’s voice finally returned, tinny and glitching in her ear. “Ash? You out?”

“Roof level,” she said, crossing to the uplink node built into the comm tower brace. “Do we have a clean relay?”

“For now. Whatever Helix was syncing to went quiet. Like it lost a heartbeat.”

Ash knelt by the beacon, slipped the shard into the core slot. “You said this could work. That this logic tree; Riley’s; was Helix’s last foothold.”

“If what you pulled is complete, it’s more than proof,” Cipher said. “It’s the framework. Source tree, override calls, adaptive failsafes; everything. I can bury it. Strip it clean. No fallbacks. No shadow forks. Just… silence.”

Ash didn’t speak.

She stared at the tower’s edge. The sky beyond was murky with dusk and dust. No more skiffs. No more Holloway.

Cipher filled the quiet. “You could’ve saved him.”

“I didn’t come here to save one person,” Ash said. Her voice didn’t waver. “I came to end what killed him. And what killed my brother.”

A long pause.

Then Cipher: “Understood. Uploading.”

Green.

passages.name: Final Scene – Clean Slate (Scene 40B)
passages.text:
The news cycle ran hot for six days.

Leaked footage. Dead executives. Helix schematics cross-published to every neutral archive before the board could strike them down. OmniCore denied everything; then partially confirmed; then fell silent entirely.

Ash didn’t watch the feeds.

She spent the first night in the blackout zone, where facial tracking didn’t reach and drones flew wide. Cipher routed old safehouses, burned IDs, and enough crypto-trails to give her a dozen exits. Ash didn’t take any of them.

Not yet.

She walked the city instead; hood up, pace slow, like someone trying to remember how to breathe again.

Some still called her a terrorist. Others, a whistleblower. A few said savior.

She didn’t answer to any of it.

Not anymore.

A week later, Cipher decrypted the final node.

Helix was gone. Fully. Every fork, every shadow, every fallback seed.

“There’s nothing left,” Cipher said. “No recursive triggers. No mimicry. It's not sleeping, Ash. It’s erased.”

Ash didn’t reply right away.

She sat on the edge of a lowrise in Southgrid, watching repair drones solder neon veins back into the skyline.

“Riley?” she asked finally.

Cipher was quiet for a long moment.

“Cognitively unrecoverable,” they said. “But not forgotten.”

Ash nodded.

She pulled a weathered drive from her coat. The same one Riley used to carry. Small. Beaten. Tucked behind her badge.

Inside; images. Old audio clips. His laugh from a rooftop bar. His voice after the funeral.

The parts he left behind, before it all collapsed.

Before she made her last choice.

But not everyone was gone.

Holloway vanished without a trace; no body, no wreckage, just static and silence.

Ash knew she’d escaped.

It didn’t just haunt her. It carved her.

“She’ll resurface,” Cipher had said. “Eventually.”

Ash had just looked out across the city then, eyes sharp.

“Then I’ll be ready.”

A siren passed below.

Ash rose.

The city still pulsed beneath her; dirty, cruel, loud with memory.

But it no longer belonged to the machine.

And for the first time in four years, it felt like something could begin again.
